regulating private access to and use of the public ways are fully paid by the
persons seeking such access and causing such costs;
(9)   Secure fair and reasonable compensation to the city and the residents of
the city for permitting private use of the public ways;
(10)   Assure that cable service providers comply with the ordinances, rules,
and regulations of the city;
(11)   Assure that the city can continue to fairly and responsibly protect the
public health, safety and welfare;
(12)   Enable the city to discharge its public trust consistent with rapidly
evolving federal and state regulatory policies, industry competition and
technological development.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 1, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-32. Definitions.
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivation shall have the meaning given as set forth hereinafter. When not
inconsistent with the context, words in the present tense include the future,
and words in the plural number include the singular number. Words not defined
shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. The word "shall" is mandatory
and the word "may" is permissive.
Additional services means video programming or cable service for which an
additional charge is required of a subscriber beyond the charge for basic
service tier and cable programming tier services, including, but not limited
to, pay-per-view movies and concerts, variety acts and sporting events, pay-
per-view programs and interactive services.
Basic cable services or basic service shall have the meaning set forth in the
Cable Act.
Cable Act shall mean the Cable Communication Policy Act of 1984, the Cable
Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1996, and the
Telecommunications Act of 1996, codified at 47 U.S.C. § 521 et seq., as it may
be amended or succeeded.
Cable programming services means those services provided on the cable
programming service tier, as such term is defined in the Cable Act.
Cable service shall have the meaning set forth in the Cable Act.
Cable service provider means and includes every person who provides cable
service over a cable system.
Cable system shall have the meaning set forth in the Cable Act.
Channel shall mean a portion of the electro-magnetic frequency spectrum (or any
other means of transmission, including, but not limited to, optical fibers)
which is capable of carrying the equivalent of a standard six MHz television
broadcast signal and includes uses of all or any portion of such band of
frequencies.
City means the City of Asheville.
City council means the City Council of the City of Asheville.
City property shall mean and include all real property owned by the city, other
then public rights-of-way as defined hereinafter.
Commercial subscriber means a subscriber who lawfully receives a service in a
place of business where the service may be utilized in connection with a
business, trade, or profession.
Complaint means a verbal or written indication from a subscriber of a problem
with any aspect of cable service.
Days means calendar days unless otherwise specified.
Drop shall mean a coaxial connection from the activated feeder cable of the
cable system to the subscribers's demarcation point as specified by the FCC.
Educational channel or educational access channel means any channel provided by
the franchisee which is designated by the city for educational use, consistent
with the Cable Act.
FCC or the Federal Communications Commission shall mean the federal
administrative agency, or its lawful successor, authorized to regulate and
oversee telecommunications carriers, services, and providers on a national
level.
Franchise means a grant from the city to a franchisee pursuant to state and
federal law, granting to the franchisee the nonexclusive and revocable right to
construct, operate, and maintain a cable system along the public rights-of-way
within the franchise area and/or to provide cable services within the franchise
area. Any such authorization, in whatever form granted, shall not mean or
include any license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and
carrying on a business within the city as required by other ordinances, rules,
and regulations of the city.
Franchise area shall mean the entire corporate limits of the city, or portions
thereof, as said areas are specifically described in the franchise, and any
area annexed by the city during the term of the franchise.
Franchisee shall mean any person who has been legally granted a franchise by
the city and shall include the lawful successor, transferee, or assignee of
such franchisee.
Franchise fee means the percentage, as specified in the franchise, of the
franchisee's gross annual revenues paid to the city in exchange for the rights
granted pursuant to this chapter.
Government channel or government access channel means any channel provided by
the franchisee which is designated by the city for government use, consistent
with the Cable Act.
Gross annual revenues means all revenues derived directly or indirectly by the
franchisee, affiliates, subsidiaries, or any other person in which the
franchisee has a financial interest, from operation of the cable system within
the franchise area, including, but not limited to: basic and tier services;
premium and pay-per-view services; leased access; installation; connection;
Internet; home shopping; equipment charges; non-entertainment services; trades
and goods or services. Gross revenues shall exclude government imposed taxes,
fees, or assessments, which are excluded pursuant to the Cable Act, bad debt,
refunds, and credits. Gross revenues shall not include the revenue of any
person, including, without limitation, a supplier of programming to the
franchisee, to the extent that said revenue is also included in the gross
revenues of the franchisee.
Installation shall mean the connection of the system from the feeder cable to
the subscribers' terminal(s).
Institutional service means such video, audio, data, or other services provided
to or among institutional users. These may include, but are not limited to,
one-way video, two-way video, audio or data transmitted among institutions.
Laws and regulations means any and all applicable federal, state, and local
laws and regulations promulgated thereunder.
Leased access channel or commercial access channel shall have the meaning set
forth in the Cable Act.
Overhead facilities means utility poles, utility facilities and associated
equipment located above the surface of the ground, including the underground
supports and foundations for such facilities.
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
limited liability company, or organization of any kind or any lawful successor
thereto or transferee thereof.
Plant mile means a linear mile of strand-bearing cable as measured on the
street or easement from pole to pole or pedestal to pedestal.
Public access channel or community access channel means any channel provided by
the franchisee to the city which is designated by the city for use by the
general public or non-commercial organizations, consistent with the Cable Act.
Public right-of-way shall mean the surface, the air space above the surface,
and the area below the surface of any highway, street, alley, sidewalk, bridge,
tunnel, utility easements, or other public right-of-way located within the
franchise area.
Resident means any person residing in the city as otherwise defined by
applicable law.
Residential subscriber means a subscriber who lawfully receives a service in an
individual dwelling unit where the service is not to be utilized in connection
with a business, trade, or profession.
Sale shall include any sale, exchange, barter, or similar transaction.
School means any public or nonprofit educational institution including primary
and secondary schools, colleges and universities, both public and private.
Small cable system operators means any cable system provider serving 1500
subscribers or less.
State means the State of North Carolina.
Subscriber means any person who lawfully receives a service provided by the
franchisee by means of or in connection with a cable system.
System facilities means the cable system constructed for use within the city,
including, without limitation, the headend, antenna, cables, wires, lines,
towers, amplifiers, converters, property security systems, equipment or
facilities located within the corporate limits of the city designed,
constructed, or wired for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying and
distributing by coaxial cable, fiber optics, microwave or other means, audio,
radio, television, and electronic signals to and from subscribers in the city,
and any other equipment or facilities located within the corporate limits of
the city intended for the use of the cable system; provided, however, such
system facilities excludes buildings, contracts, facilities and equipment where
its sole use is for providing service to other system facilities located
outside the city limits.
Transfer means the disposal by the franchisee, directly or indirectly, by gift,
assignment, voluntary sale, merger, consolidation or otherwise, of ten percent
or more of the assets, stock, title, rights, or other interest of, in, or to
the cable system at one time or cumulatively over the term of the franchise of
such interest to any other corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust
or association, or person or group of persons acting in concert, subject to
subsection
4.5-57(b).
Trunk line means the major distribution cable used in the cable system, which
divides into the feeder lines which are tapped for service to subscribers.
Upstream signal means a signal originating from a terminal to another point in
the cable system.
User means a person or organization utilizing channel or equipment and
facilities for the purpose of producing and/or transmission of material, as
contrasted with the receipt thereof in a subscriber capacity.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 2, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-33. Registration of cable services providers.
(a)   Required. Unless prohibited by other laws and regulations or unless a
cable service provider has an existing franchise with the city, all cable
services providers that offer or provide any cable service for a fee directly
to the public, either within the city, or outside the corporate limits, from
facilities within the city, shall register with the city pursuant to this
section on forms to be provided by the city clerk, which shall include the
following:
(1)   The identity and legal status of the registrant, including any
affiliates.
(2)   The name, address, and telephone number of the officer, agent, or
employee responsible for the accuracy of the registration statement.
(3)   A description of the registrant's existing or proposed facilities within
the city.
(4)   A description of the cable services that the registrant intends to offer
or provide, or is currently offering or providing, to persons within the city.
(5)   Information sufficient to determine whether the registrant is subject to
public right-of-way franchising under this chapter.
(6)   Information sufficient to determine whether the transmission, origination
or receipt of the cable services provided or to be provided by the registrant
constitutes an occupation or privilege subject to any taxes, fees, or charges
imposed by the city.
(7)   Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for
and received any permit or approval required by federal or state agencies to
provide cable services within the city.
(8)   Information sufficient to determine that the applicant has applied for
and received any construction permit, operating license or other approvals
required by the FCC to provide cable services or facilities within the city.
(9)   Such other information as the city may reasonably require.
(b)   Fee. Each application for registration as a cable services provider shall
be accompanied by a registration fee of $25.00.
(c)   Purpose. The purpose of registration under this chapter is to:
(1)   Provide the city with accurate and current information concerning the
cable service providers who offer or provide cable services within the city, or
that own or operate cable systems within the city;
(2)   Assist the city in enforcement of this chapter;
(3)   Assist the city in the collection and enforcement of any municipal taxes,
franchise fees or other fees or charges that may be due the city;
(4)   Assist the city in monitoring compliance with laws and regulations.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 3, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-34. Franchise required.
Unless prohibited by other laws and regulations, no person shall operate,
construct, or maintain a cable system on the public rights-of-way of the city
without a franchise.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 4, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-35. Cable services franchise.
(a)   The city may, at its sole option, grant to a person the non-exclusive
right, privilege and authority to construct, operate, maintain, repair,
replace, rebuild and reconstruct a cable system to provide cable service within
a franchise area.
(b)   Except as may be otherwise provided herein or as otherwise regulated or
prohibited by other applicable laws and regulations, any cable services
provider who desires to construct, install, operate, maintain or otherwise
locate a cable system in, under, over or across any public rights-of-way, and/
or also provide cable services to persons or areas in the city shall first
obtain a franchise from the city pursuant to this chapter.
(c)   Franchise application. Unless the city determines otherwise, any person
that desires a franchise pursuant to this chapter shall file an application
with the city which shall include the information, in a format requested by the
city, as follows:
(1)   The identity of the franchise applicant, including all affiliates of the
applicant.
(2)   A description of the cable services that will be offered or provided by
the franchise applicant and whether such services will be provided over an
existing or proposed cable system or on a cable system owned by another cable
services provider.
(3)   A description of the transmission medium that will be used by the
franchisee to offer or provide its cable services.
(4)   Preliminary engineering plans, specifications and network map of the
facilities to be located within the city, all in sufficient detail to identify:
a.   The location and route requested for the applicant's proposed cable
system.
b.   The location of all overhead and underground public utility,
telecommunication, cable, water, sewer drainage and other facilities in the
public right-of-way along the proposed route.
c.   When known at the time the application is made the specific trees,
structures, improvements, facilities, and obstructions, if any, that the
applicant proposes to temporarily or permanently remove or relocate; otherwise,
applicant shall furnish this information as soon as it is known.
(5)   If the applicant is proposing to install overhead facilities, and if the
information is known by the applicant, evidence that surplus space is available
for locating its cable system on existing utility poles along the proposed
route.
(6)   If the applicant is proposing an underground installation in existing
ducts or conduits within the public rights-of-way, if the information is known
by the applicant, information in sufficient detail to identify:
a.   The excess capacity currently available in such ducts or conduits before
installation of applicant's cable system;
b.   The excess capacity, if any, that will exist in such ducts or conduits
after installation of applicant's cable system.
(7)   If applicant is proposing an underground installation within new ducts or
conduits to be constructed with in the public rights-of-way:
a.   The location proposed for the new ducts or conduits;
b.   The excess capacity that will exist in such ducts or conduits after
installation of applicant's cable system.
(8)   A preliminary construction schedule and completion dates.
(9)   A preliminary traffic control plan.
(10)   Financial statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted
accounting principals demonstrating the applicant's financial ability to
construct, operate, maintain, relocate and remove the cable system and/or
provide cable services.
(11)   Information in sufficient detail to establish the applicant's technical
qualifications, experience and expertise regarding the cable system and
services described in the application.
(12)   Information to establish that the applicant has obtained all other
necessary governmental approvals and permits to construct and operate the cable
system and/or to offer or provide the cable services.
(13)   Whether the applicant intends to provide cable service, open video
systems or other video programming service, and sufficient information to
determine whether such service is subject to cable system or cable service
franchising.
(14)   An accurate map showing the location of any existing system facilities
in the city that the applicant intends to use or lease.
(15)   A description of the services or facilities that the applicant will
offer or make available to the city and other public, educational and
governmental institutions.
(16)   A description of the applicant's access and/or line extension policies.
(17)   The area or areas of the city the applicant desires to serve and a
schedule for build-out to the entire franchise area.
(18)   All fees, deposits or charges required pursuant to this chapter and/or
the Fees and Charges Manual of the city. Unless provided otherwise in the
franchise, any applicant for a new franchise or for a renewal of a franchise
granted pursuant to this chapter shall pay an application fee of $2,500.00 to
the city, which shall be a non-refundable fee. In addition, the applicant shall
reimburse the city for all fees and costs incurred by the city which are
associated with the initial grant of a franchise, which payment of fees and
costs shall become a material term of the franchise.
(19)   Such other and further information as may be reasonably requested by the
city manager or city council.
(d)   Determination by the city. After receiving a complete application under
subsection (c) hereof, the city shall review the application and issue a
written determination granting or denying the application in whole or in part,
applying the following standards. If the application is denied, the written
determination shall include the reasons for denial.
(1)   The financial and technical ability of the applicant.
(2)   The legal ability of the applicant.
(3)   The capacity of the public rights-of-way to accommodate the applicant's
proposed cable system.
(4)   The capacity of the public rights-of-way to accommodate additional
utility and cable systems if the franchise is granted.
(5)   The damage or disruption, if any, of public or private facilities,
improvements, service, travel or landscaping if the franchise is granted.
(6)   The public interest in minimizing the cost and disruption of construction
within the public rights-of-way.
(7)   The service that the applicant will provide to the community and region.
(8)   The effect, if any, on public health, safety and welfare if the franchise
is granted.
(9)   The availability of alternate routes and/or locations for the proposed
facilities of the cable system.
(10)   Applicable laws and regulations.
(11)   Such other factors as may demonstrate that the grant to use of the
public right-of-way will serve the community interest.
(e)   Agreement. No franchise granted under this chapter shall be effective
until the applicant and the city have negotiated and executed a written
agreement setting forth the particular terms and provisions under which the
franchise to occupy and use public rights-of-way of the city will be granted.
(f)   Non-exclusive grant. No franchise granted under this chapter shall confer
any exclusive right, privilege, license or franchise to occupy or use the
public rights-of-way of the city for delivery of cable services or any other
purposes.
(g)   Rights granted. No franchise granted under this chapter shall convey any
right, title or interest in the public rights-of-way, but shall be deemed a
license only to use and occupy the public rights-of-way for the limited
purposes and term stated in the grant. Further, no franchise shall be construed
as any warranty of title.
(h)   Term of grant. A franchise granted hereunder shall be valid for a term as
set forth in the franchise. A franchisee owning a cable system shall have no
right to use of public rights-of-way upon the completion of the franchise term.
(i)   Franchise area. A franchise granted under this chapter shall apply to the
franchise area as described in the franchise.
(j)   Location of facilities. Unless otherwise specified in the franchise
agreement, all facilities shall be constructed, installed and located in
accordance with the following terms and conditions:
(1)   The franchisee shall use reasonable efforts to install its facilities
within an existing underground duct or conduit whenever excess capacity exists
within such utility facility and whenever the franchisee deems it technically
and operationally desirable.
(2)   A franchisee with permission to install overhead facilities may install
the facilities for its cable system on pole attachments to existing utility
poles only.
(3)   Whenever all existing electric and telephone utilities, cable facilities
or facilities are located underground within the public rights-of-way in the
city, a franchise with permission to occupy the same public rights- of-way must
also locate its facilities for its cable system underground. In such
situations, the franchisee shall use reasonable efforts to joint trench with
the other utilities.
(4)   Whenever all new or existing electric utilities, or facilities for a
cable system are located or relocated underground within a public right-of-way
in the city, a franchisee that currently occupies the same public right-of-way
shall relocate its facilities underground within a reasonable period of time,
which shall not be later than the end of the franchise term. In such
situations, the franchisee shall use reasonable efforts to joint trench with
the other utilities. Absent extraordinary circumstances or undue hardship, such
relocation shall be made concurrently to minimize the disruption of the public
rights-of-way.
(k)   Construction permits. All franchisees for cable systems are required to
obtain construction permits for construction of facilities for a cable system
and for other permits as required by applicable laws and regulations.
(l)   Amendment of franchise. A new application for and an amendment to a
franchise shall be required of any cable services provider that desires to
extend or locate its cable system in public rights-of-way of the city which are
not included in the franchise area previously described in a franchise granted
under this chapter.
(m)   Franchise renewal. Upon completion of the term of any franchise granted
under this chapter to provide cable service, the city may grant or deny renewal
of the franchise of the franchisee in accordance with the provisions of the
Cable Act.
If the Cable Act ceases to provide a procedure and/or other requirements for a
franchise renewal, the city may grant or deny renewal of the franchise of the
franchisee in accordance with the provisions of the Cable Act which were in
effect immediately prior to the Cable Act ceasing to so provide, provided this
provision is enforceable and/or not pre-empted by federal law.
(n)   Obligation to cure as a condition of renewal. Unless otherwise provided
or prohibited by other applicable laws and regulations, no franchise shall be
renewed until any ongoing violations or defaults in the franchisee's
performance under the franchise, or of the requirements of this chapter or
other applicable laws or regulations, have been cured, or a plan detailing the
corrective action to be taken by the franchisee has been approved by the city.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 5, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-36. Franchise fees.
(a)   Generally. The city hereby determines and declares that the public
rights-of-way to be used by the franchisee in the operation of its franchise
are valuable public properties acquired and maintained by the city and state at
great expense to their taxpayers; that the grant to the franchisee is a
valuable property right without which the franchisee would be required to
invest substantial capital in right-of-way costs and acquisitions; and that the
administration of this chapter and the franchise impose upon the city
regulatory and administrative responsibility and expense. For that reason, the
franchisee shall pay to the city a franchise fee in an amount as designated in
the franchise, but in no event less than five percent of the gross annual
revenues. This annual franchise fee shall be in addition to any other fee and
the obligation to pay such fee shall commence on the effective date of the
franchise, unless otherwise provided by the franchise.
(b)   Other assessments, taxes or fees. The franchise fee required hereunder is
in addition to all other lawful fees, assessments, taxes or payments that the
franchisee may be required under any laws and regulations.
(c)   Payment schedule and reports. The franchisee shall make quarterly
payments to the city of the franchisee fee for the quarters ending on September
30, December 31, March 31 and June 30 of each year, with the payments due from
the franchisee to the city within 45 days after the end of each quarter. At the
time of each quarterly payment, the franchisee shall furnish to the city a
report certified by a certified public accountant showing complete calculations
on which the payment of the franchise fee is based, with such calculations
based upon data separately shown for only that portion of the cable system of
the franchisee which is located within the franchise area. On or before April
1, 2003, and on or before April 1, 2008, the franchisee shall provide to the
city, at no cost to the city, an independent audit, prepared by a certified
public accountant, of the franchise fee payments made to the city for the five
previous calendar year periods (1998-2002 on or before April 1, 2003, and 2003-
2007 on or before April 1, 2008).
(d)   Acceptance by the city. No acceptance of any payment by the city shall be
construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the city
may have for further or additional sums payable as a franchise fee under this
chapter or the franchise or for the performance of any other obligation of the
franchisee under this chapter or the franchise.
(e)   Failure to make required payment. In the event that any franchise payment
or recomputed amount is not made on or before the dates specified herein, the
franchisee shall pay as additional compensation an interest charge at the
annual maximum rate allowed by the state.
(f)   City's right to inspection. The city or its designee shall have the right
to inspect all of the franchisee's records which relate to gross annual
revenues and the right to audit and to recompute any amounts determined to be
payable under this chapter and/or the franchise. Audits other than those
required pursuant to section 4.5(c), shall be at the expense of the city,
provided, however, the franchisee shall immediately reimburse the city for all
reasonable audit expenses of the city in the event the audit conducted shows
that franchise fee payments or other payments due to the city are in error in
the amount of five percent or more. Unless contested in writing by the
franchisee, the cost of the audit (if applicable) and any additional amount due
to the city as a result of the audit shall be paid within 30 days following
written notice to the franchisee by the city, which notice shall include a copy
of the city's audit report.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 6, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-37. Regulatory authority.
(a)   On-going regulation. The city shall exercise its regulatory authority in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and in accordance with and
pursuant to applicable laws and regulations. This authority shall be vested in
the city council and administered through the city manager or his designee or
the city's designee. The city manager, his designee or the city's designee
shall provide day-to-day administration and enforcement of the provisions of
this chapter and any franchise granted hereunder, and shall carry out the
city's responsibilities with regard to cable services.
(b)   Governing requirement. At all times during the term of the franchise, the
franchisee shall comply with all laws and regulations which are now applicable
or may be applicable hereafter to the construction and operation of cable
systems, including without limitation, all laws and regulations now in force or
hereafter enacted. Nothing herein shall be deemed a waiver of the franchisee's
right to challenge the validity of any such laws or regulations.
(c)   Change in laws or regulations. Notwithstanding any other provisions of
this chapter to the contrary, the franchisee shall at all times comply with all
laws and regulations. In the event that any actions of the state or federal
government or any agency thereof, or any court of competent jurisdiction upon
final adjudication, substantially reduce in any way the power or authority of
the city under this chapter or the franchise, the city, at its option, may
notify the franchisee that it wishes to negotiate those provisions which are
affected in any way by such modification in laws or regulations. Thereafter,
the franchisee shall negotiate in good faith with the city in the development
of alternate provisions which shall fairly restore the city to the maximum
level of authority and power permitted by laws and regulations. Subject to
applicable laws and regulations, the franchisee shall have the duty, based upon
the results of such negotiations, to modify any of the provisions to such
reasonable extent as may be necessary to carry out the full intent and purposes
of this chapter and the franchise.
If the FCC no longer provides for any of the standards, rules or regulations as
described or referred to in this chapter, the city shall have the option to
adopt the FCC standards, rules or regulations in effect immediately prior to
the date the FCC no longer provides for the standards, rules or regulations,
provided that this provision is enforceable and/or not preempted by state or
federal law.
(d)   Authority. The city reserves the right to exercise the maximum plenary
authority, as may at any time be lawfully permissible, to regulate the cable
system, the franchise and the franchisee. Should applicable legislative,
judicial or regulatory authorities at any time permit regulation not presently
permitted to the city, the city may engage in any such additional regulation as
may then be permissible, whether or not contemplated by this chapter or the
franchise, including without limitation, regulation regarding franchise fees,
taxes, programming, rates charged to subscribers and users, consumer
protection, or any other similar or dissimilar matter.
(e)   Right of inspection of records. Unless otherwise provided in the
franchise, after seven days written notice to the franchisee, the city or its
designee shall have the right to inspect all books, records, reports, maps,
plans, financial statements, and other like materials of the franchisee which
relate to the franchise or this chapter, at any time during normal business
hours. The franchisee shall provide such information in such form as may be
reasonably required by the city for said records.
(f)   Right of inspection of cable system. The city or its designee shall have
the right to inspect all facilities and appurtenant property of the cable
system and installation work on the cable system performed subject to the
provisions of the franchise. After written notice to the franchisee, the city
or its designee shall have the right to make such tests as it shall find
necessary to ensure compliance with the terms of this chapter and other
pertinent provisions of laws and regulations. The franchisee shall have the
right to have a representative present during inspections or testing conducted
by the city or its designee. The city shall conduct such investigations in a
manner that avoids unreasonable interference with the delivery of cable service
to subscribers.
(g)   Expense reimbursement to city. Unless otherwise agreed to by the city,
the franchisee shall pay the city a sum of money which will, when added to any
application fees received, reimburse all costs and expenses incurred by it in
connection with the granting, extending, or renewing a franchise, including,
but not limited to, consultant fees, attorneys' fees, publication fees, travel
expenses and all other direct costs; provided, however, that the city shall
submit a detailed schedule of all such costs. Such payment shall be made within
30 days after the city furnishes the franchisee with a written statement of
such expenses.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 7, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-38. Supervision of the franchise.
(a)   Subject to applicable laws and regulations, the city shall have the
following additional regulatory authority:
(1)   Administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and any
franchise granted hereunder.
(2)   Award, renewal, extension or termination of a franchise pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter, the franchise, and other applicable laws and
regulations.
(3)   Consent prior to sale or transfer of any franchise granted hereunder.
(4)   Performance evaluation.
(5)   Receive and investigate complaints regarding subscriber service and to
initiate any action necessary pursuant to and in accordance with this chapter
or the franchise or any applicable laws or regulations to address the
complaints.
(6)   Rate regulation, if applicable.
(b)   Subject to applicable laws and regulations, the city also reserves the
right to perform the following functions:
(1)   Develop objectives and coordinate activities related to the operation of
public, government and educational channels.
(2)   Approve procedures and standards for public, government and educational
channels and operations and services, including the use of those channels and
sharing of public facilities.
(3)   Coordinate plans with franchisees for expansion, interconnection and
growth of cable services.
(4)   Formulate and recommend long-range cable services policy for the city,
and determine the future cable services needs and interests of the community.
(5)   Provide the administrative effort necessary for the conduct of
performance evaluations, and any other activities required for the
administration of this chapter and the franchise.
(6)   Monitor the franchisee's process for handling citizen complaints and
periodically inspect and analyze the records related to such complaints.
(7)   Receive applications for rate increases, if applicable, and provide staff
assistance in the analysis and recommendations thereto.
(8)   Monitor the franchisee's adherence to operational standards, service
requirements and line extension policies.
(9)   Assure compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
(10)   Arrange tests and analysis of equipment and performance, as needed to
insure compliance with this chapter and the franchise.
(11)   Receive for examination all data and reports required by or requested
pursuant to this chapter or the franchise.
(12)   Represent the city's interest before local, state or federal government
agencies in cable service matters.
(13)   Such other regulatory authority as may be lawful to carry out the intent
of this chapter and the franchise.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 8, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-39. Services to subscribers and institutions.
(a)   Programming. Concurrently with the activation of the cable in the city,
the franchisee shall provide all services to subscribers as described herein.
(1)   Diversity. The system shall carry the broad categories of programming and
services listed in the franchise. Should the franchisee desire to change the
selection of programs or services offered on any of its tiers, it shall
maintain the mix and quality of services provided over the cable system. Any
such change in programs or services offered shall comply with the conditions
and procedures contained in the franchise, and shall be reported to the city at
least 30 days prior to the proposed implementation, unless a different time
period is required by applicable laws and regulations. The franchisee shall use
its best efforts to ensure diversity of programming.
(2)   Basic service tier. Consistent with the Cable Act, a basic service tier
shall be offered to subscribers throughout the term of the franchise.
(3)   Access channels. The franchisee shall provide and maintain access
channels as specified in the franchise.
(4)   Leased access. Consistent with the Cable Act, the franchisee shall make
available leased access channels to assure that the widest possible diversity
of information sources are made available to subscribers.
(5)   Access services. The franchisee shall fully provide, at a minimum,
services, facilities and equipment for public, educational, and government
access as indicated in the franchise.
(b)   Institutional network. The franchisee shall construct, install, operate
and maintain a separate institutional network, in addition to the residential
subscriber network as specified in the franchise.
(c)   Emergency override. The franchisee shall, without charge, provide service
and maintain public emergency transmission facilities to the city, as described
in the franchise.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 9, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-40. Installations, connections, and other services.
(a)   Standard installations. Standard installation shall consist of a service
not exceeding 150 feet from the activated feeder cable of the cable system.
Service in excess of 150 feet and concealed wiring shall be charged at such
cost as exceeds normal installation costs in compliance with the terms of the
franchise. The desire of the subscriber as to the point of entry into the
residence or commercial establishment and location of pedestal shall be
observed whenever possible. Runs in building interiors shall be as unobtrusive
as possible. The franchisee shall use due care in the process of installation
and shall repair any damage to the subscriber's property caused by said
installation. Such restoration shall be undertaken within no more than ten days
after the damage is incurred and shall be completed as soon as possible
thereafter.
(b)   Reconnection. The franchisee shall restore service to subscribers wishing
restoration of service provided subscriber shall first satisfy any previous
obligations owed, and subject to any other reasonable requirements or
restrictions of the franchisee.
(c)   Free disconnection. Unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
subscriber, subscribers shall have the right to have cable service disconnected
without charge. A refund of unused service charges shall be paid to the
subscriber within 30 days from the date of termination of service or the next
billing cycle.
(d)   Delinquent accounts. The franchisee shall use its best efforts to collect
on delinquent subscriber accounts. In all cases, the franchisee shall provide
the subscriber with adequate notice prior to disconnection in a manner
consistent with applicable laws and regulations.
(e)   Installation. Consistent with the FCC customer service standards, or
successor standards adopted by the city, the franchisee shall install cable
service to a subscriber within seven business days of request by the
subscriber.
(f)   Outages. The franchisee, upon a subscriber's request, shall credit or
issue a refund to the subscriber for verifiable outages of six hours or more in
duration for the levels of service affected by such outages.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 10, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-41. Service calls and complaint procedures.
(a)   Business offices and personnel. The franchisee shall establish and
maintain a business office within the corporate limits of the city which shall,
at a minimum, be open to receive payments and subscriber equipment for the
hours specified in the FCC customer service regulations in effect as of the
commencement date of the franchise. If the FCC adopts higher customer service
standards during the term of the franchise, the franchisee shall comply with
the higher customer service standards of the FCC. Consistent with the FCC's
customer service standards, the franchisee shall also provide personnel,
telephone service, including a locally listed telephone number, and other
equipment as needed within the franchise area, to ensure timely, efficient and
effective service to subscribers and for the purpose of receiving inquiries,
requests and complaints concerning all aspects of the construction,
installation, operation, and maintenance of the cable system and for the
payment of subscribers' service charges.
(b)   Standards. The franchisee shall meet the FCC's customer service
standards. If the franchisee does not meet the FCC's telephone answering-busy
signal standards for a quarter, the franchisee shall add a minimum of one
telephone line or make other changes in order to satisfy the FCC's standards.
Upon request of the city, the franchisee shall provide to the city; annual
management data, including data from any service centers used by the franchisee
related to compliance with the FCC's customer service standards. At such time
as the franchisee does not meet the FCC and/or the customer service standards
of this chapter for repair for one quarter, the franchisee shall take
corrective action to ensure that such standards are met during the next
quarter.
(c)   Franchisee rules. Upon request of the city, the franchisee shall prepare
and file with the city copies of all of its rules and regulations in connection
with the handling of inquiries, requests and complaints. The franchisee shall,
by appropriate means, such as a card or brochure, furnish information
concerning the procedures for making inquiries or complaints, including the
name, address and local telephone number of the employee or employees or agent
to whom such inquiries or complaints are to be addressed, and furnish
information concerning the city office responsible for the administration of
the franchise, including, but not limited to, the address and telephone number
of said office.
(d)   Complaint records. The franchisee shall keep full records in connection
with all inquiries, complaints and requests in connection with the cable
system. Such records shall identify the person contacting the franchisee, and
the person responding on behalf of the franchisee, the subject matter of the
contact, the date and time it was received, the resolution of the matter in
question or the action taken by the franchisee in connection with the contact,
and the date and time thereof, and such other information as may be deemed
pertinent by the franchisee. These records shall be made available at the
franchisee's office for periodic inspection by the city.
(e)   Equipment service. Consistent with the FCC's regulations, the franchisee
shall service or replace without charge all equipment provided by it to the
subscriber, provided, however, that the franchisee may charge a subscriber for
service to or replacement of any equipment damaged as a result of the
subscriber's conduct.
(f)   Subscriber solicitation. Upon request of the city, the franchisee shall
provide the city with a list of names and addresses of all representatives who
will be soliciting within the city and the area in and the dates within such
solicitations shall take place. Each such representative and all other
employees entering upon private property shall be required to wear an employee
identification card issued by the franchisee and bearing a picture of said
representative.
(g)   Subscriber information. The franchisee shall provide to all subscribers
annually and all prospective subscribers or users with complete written
information concerning all services and rates provided by the franchisee upon
solicitation of service and prior to consummation of any agreement for
installation of service. Such sales material shall clearly and conspicuously
disclose the price and other information concerning the franchisee's least
costly service. Such information shall be written in plain English and shall
include but shall not be limited to the following: all services, tiers, and
rates; deposits if applicable; installation costs; additional television set
charges; service upgrade or downgrade charges; lockout devices; and information
concerning the utilization of video cassette recorders (VCRs) with cable
services and the cost for hooking up such VCRs so that they function as
manufactured.
(h)   Billing practices information. Consistent with FCC standards, the
franchisee shall inform all subscribers annually and all prospective
subscribers or users of complete information respecting billing and collection
procedures, procedures for ordering changes in or termination of services, and
refund policies, upon solicitation of service and prior to the consummation of
any agreement for installation of service. The franchisee shall provide its
name, address and telephone number on subscribers bills. All information
required herein shall be written in plain English.
(i)   Notice or complaint procedures. The franchisee shall periodically, and at
various times of the day, present its business office address and publicly
listed local telephone number by means of alpha-numeric display on a local
origination channel.
(j)   Response to service complaint. Calls for repair service shall be
responded to within 24 hours. System outages, whole or partial, shall be
responded to immediately. The franchisee shall promptly resolve complaints
other than requests for repairs. The franchisee shall keep a record of all
complaints received. Upon request from the city, the franchisee shall provide
the city with records of and responses to subscriber's complaints.
(k)   Unresolved complaints. Should a subscriber or user have an unresolved
complaint after seven calendar days regarding cable system operations, the
subscriber or user shall be entitled to file his complaint with the city, which
shall have primary responsibility for the continuing administration of this
chapter and the franchise and the implementation of complaint procedures. A
representative of the franchisee shall be available thereafter to meet jointly
with the city and the affected subscriber or user, within 30 days after said
subscriber or user has filed the complaint, to fully discuss and resolve the
matter.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 11, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-42. Protection of subscriber privacy.
(a)   Protection of subscriber privacy mandatory. The franchisee shall at all
times protect the privacy of subscribers, pursuant to the Cable Act and other
applicable laws and regulations.
(b)   Notice of privacy provisions. Consistent with the Cable Act, at the time
of entering into an agreement to provide any cable service or other service to
a subscriber, and at least once a year thereafter, the franchisee shall provide
notice in the form of a separate written statement to each subscriber which
clearly and conspicuously informs the subscriber of:
(1)   The privacy rights of the subscriber and the limitations placed upon the
franchisee pursuant to the subscriber privacy provisions in applicable laws and
regulations;
(2)   The nature of personally identifiable information collected or to be
collected with respect to the subscriber and the nature of the use of such
information;
(3)   The nature, frequency, and purpose of any disclosure which may be made of
such information, including an identification of the types of persons to whom
the disclosure may be made;
(4)   The period during which such information might be maintained by the cable
operator;
(5)   The times and place at which the subscriber may have access to such
information in accordance with the Cable Act and other applicable laws and
regulations;
(6)   A request for the subscriber signature allows for use of personally
identifiable information.
(c)   Disclosure of subscriber information prohibited. Consistent with the
Cable Act, the franchisee shall not without the specific written authorization
of the individual subscribers involved, sell or otherwise make available to any
party any list of the names and addresses of individual subscribers, any list
which identifies the viewing habits of individual subscribers, or any personal
data, social security number, income and other data the company may have on
file about individual subscribers, except as necessary to render or conduct a
legitimate business activity related to a cable service or other service
provided by the cable operator to the subscriber, provided, however, that such
disclosure shall not reveal directly or indirectly the extent of viewing or
other use by the subscriber of a cable service or other service provided by the
cable operator, or the nature of any transaction made by the subscriber over
the cable system.
(d)   Correction policy. Consistent with the Cable Act, each subscriber shall
be provided access to all personally identifiable information regarding such
subscriber that the franchisee collects or maintains or allows to be collected
or maintained, and such subscriber shall be provided the opportunity to correct
any error in such information.
(e)   System performance. This section is not intended to prohibit the use or
transmission of signals useful only for the control or measurement of system
performance.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 12, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-43. Rates and charges.
(a)   Schedule filings. Consistent with the Cable Act, the franchisee shall
file with the city schedules which shall describe all services offered, all
rates and charges of any kind, and all terms and conditions relating thereto.
Unless otherwise required by laws and regulations, the franchisee shall notify
subscribers in writing at least 30 days prior to the implementation of any
change in services offered, rates charges, or terms and conditions related
thereto.
(b)   Nondiscriminatory rates. Consistent with the FCC's regulations, the
franchisee shall establish rates that are nondiscriminatory. Nothing contained
herein shall prohibit the franchisee from offering discounts or reductions such
as, but not limited to:
(1)   Discounts to commercial and multiple family dwelling subscribers billed
on a bulk basis;
(2)   Promotional discounts;
(3)   Reduced installation rates for subscribers who have multiple services; or
(4)   Discount for senior citizens and/or low income residents.
The franchisee's charges and rates for all services shall be itemized on
subscriber's monthly bills pursuant to FCC's regulations and rules.
(c)   City regulation. To the extent that laws and regulations may now, or as
the same may hereafter be amended to, authorize the city to regulate the rates
for any particular service tiers, service packages, equipment, or any other
services provided by the franchisee, the city shall have the right to exercise
rate regulation to the full extent authorized by laws and regulations, or to
refrain from exercising such regulation for any period of time, at the sole
discretion of the city.
(d)   Regulation of rates and charges. The city will follow FCC regulations and
other applicable laws and regulations as they now exist or as hereafter amended
by the FCC or other applicable governmental authorities from time to time, in
its regulation of the rates and charges of the franchisee. In connection with
such regulation, the city will ensure a reasonable opportunity for
consideration of the views of interested parties; and the city attorney, or
his/her designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the city and file with
the FCC or other governmental authority forms or other instruments as are now
or may hereafter be required by the FCC or other governmental authority in
order to enable the city to regulate the franchisee's rates and charges.
(e)   Ability to petition. If applicable, the city shall have the right to
petition the FCC or other governmental authority to obtain authority to
regulate rates and charges.
(Ord. No 2496, § 13, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-44. Performance evaluation.
(a)   Annual sessions. The city and the franchisee shall, upon 30 days written
notice from the city to the franchisee and at the discretion of the city, hold
scheduled performance evaluation sessions annually. All such evaluation
sessions shall be open to the public.
(b)   Special sessions. Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time
during the term of the franchise at the request of the city, upon written
notice by the city. Thirty days written notice must be given to the franchisee
prior to the date of a special evaluation session, which notice shall provide a
description of the subject matter to be discussed.
(c)   Topics for review. Topics which may be discussed at any scheduled or
special evaluation session may include, but not be limited to, system
performance and construction, franchisee compliance with this chapter and the
franchise, customer service and complaint response, subscriber privacy,
services provided, programming offered, service rate structures, if applicable,
franchise fees, penalties, free or discounted services, applications of new
technologies, judicial and FCC filings, and line extensions.
(d)   Cooperation by franchisee. During the review and evaluation by the city,
the franchisee shall fully cooperate with the city and shall provide such
information and documents as the city may reasonably request to perform its
review.
(e)   Response to inquiries. The city may, at any time, make written inquiries,
concerned with the management and affairs of the cable system. The franchisee
shall respond to such inquiries in a timely fashion.
(Ord. No 2496, § 14, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-45. Design and construction provisions; authority to construct.
The franchisee shall apply for and secure any needed contracts for pole use.
Pole space and other facilities obtained from the city, utilities and others,
and other lawful uses of the public rights-of-way shall be at the cost and
expense of the franchisee. The franchisee shall apply for all necessary
applications for permits, licenses, certificates and authorizations in a timely
fashion so that such filing and processing shall not interfere unreasonably
with or cause delay with the initial or rebuild construction schedule as
outlined in the franchise.
(Ord. No 2496, § 15, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-46. Construction and technical standards.
(a)   Compliance with construction and technical standards. The franchisee
shall construct, rebuild, install, operate and maintain its system in a manner
consistent with all laws and regulations, construction standards or guidelines,
governmental requirements and standards, and the FCC's technical standards
required in the franchise. The cable system shall be designed, constructed,
operated and maintained for 24-hours-a-day continuous operation.
(b)   City approval of construction plans. Prior to the erection of any towers,
poles or conduits or the upgrade or rebuild of the cable system regulated under
this chapter, the franchisee shall, consistent with the requirements in the
franchise, first submit to the city and other designated parties for approval a
concise description of the facilities proposed to be erected or installed,
including engineering drawings, if required by the city, together with a map
and plans indicating the proposed location of all such facilities. No erection
or installation of any tower, pole, underground conduit, or fixture or any
rebuilds or upgrading of the cable system shall be commenced by any person
until approval thereof has been received from the city.
(c)   Contractor qualifications. Any contractor proposed for work of
construction, installation, operation, maintenance, and repair of system
equipment must be properly licensed under applicable laws and regulations.
(d)   Minimum interference. The franchisee's cable system and associated
equipment erected by the franchisee within the city shall be so located as to
cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys, and other
public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and
reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the said streets,
alleys or other public ways and places. No pole or other fixtures placed in any
public ways by the franchisee shall be placed in such a manner as to interfere
with normal travel on such public way.
(e)   City maps. The city does not guarantee the accuracy of any maps it
furnishes to a franchisee showing the horizontal or vertical location of
existing substructures. In public rights-of-way, where necessary, the location
shall be verified by the franchise.
(f)   Quality of construction. Construction, installation, operation, and
maintenance of the cable system shall be performed in an orderly and
workmanlike manner, in accordance with then current technological and industry
standards and the manufacturer's specifications. All cables and wires shall be
installed, where possible, parallel with electric and telephone lines, in
accordance with applicable laws and regulations. Multiple cable configurations
shall be arranged in parallel and bundled with due respect for aesthetic and
engineering considerations.
(g)   Construction standards. The construction, installation, operation,
maintenance, and/or removal of the cable system shall meet all of the
applicable safety, construction, and technical specifications of the following
codes and standards:
Occupational Safety and Health Administration Regulations (OSHA).
National Electrical Code.
National Electrical Safety Code (NESC).
National Cable Television Standard Code.
AT&T Manual of Construction Procedures (Blue Book).
Bell Telephone Systems Code of Pole Line Construction.
All federal, state and municipal construction requirements, including FCC rules
and regulations.
Utility construction requirements.
All building and zoning codes, and all land use restrictions as the same exist
or may be amended hereafter.
(h)   Right to inspection of construction. The city or its designee shall have
the right to inspect at any time all construction or installation work
performed subject to the provisions of this chapter and the franchise and to
make such tests as it shall deem necessary to ensure compliance with the terms
of this chapter, the franchise and all other applicable laws and regulations.
The franchisee shall cooperate fully with the city during all inspections and
tests and shall provide access to all equipment, records, and other materials
and information necessary for such inspections and tests. Except as otherwise
provided by this chapter, the franchise or laws and regulations, all
inspections and tests performed by the city shall be at the city's sole cost
and expense.
(i)   Antennas. Any antenna structure used in the cable system shall comply
with construction, marking, and lighting of antenna structure standards as
required by city ordinances and by other applicable laws and regulations.
(j)   OSHA. All worker facilities, conditions, and procedures that are used
during construction, installation, operation, and maintenance of the cable
system shall comply with the standards of the Occupational Safety and Health
Administration.
(k)   RF leakage. RF leakage shall be checked and stray radiation shall be
measured according to FCC rules and regulations. The cable system shall be
operated and maintained so as to avoid any measurable interference in TV signal
reception to any operating receiver not connected to and serviced by the cable
system.
(l)   Standby power. The franchisee shall maintain equipment capable of
providing standby power for a minimum of eight hours for the headend and 2½
hours at a node site.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 16, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-47. As-built drawings.
Within 60 days after completion of construction, including without limitation
construction of a rebuild of the cable system; the franchisee shall furnish the
city with one complete set of plans, drawn to scale and certified by a
registered professional engineer to the city as accurately depicting the
location of those portions of the cable system which have been constructed.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 17, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-48. Use of street.
(a)   Underground installation. All installations shall be underground in those
areas of the city where public utilities providing both telephone and electric
service are underground at the time of installation. In areas where either
telephone or electric utility facilities are above ground at the time of
installation, the franchisee may install its service above ground, provided
that at such time as both those facilities are placed underground, the
franchisee shall likewise place its services underground without cost to the
city. Where not otherwise required to be placed underground by this chapter or
the franchise, the franchisee's cable system shall be located underground at
the request of the adjacent property owner, provided that the excess cost over
the aerial location shall be borne by the property owner making the request.
For installations after the effective date of this chapter, all cable passing
under the roadway shall be installed in conduit.
(b)   Pedestals. In any cases which pedestals housing mini-hubs, switching or
other equipment, are to be utilized, such equipment must be installed in
accordance with applicable laws and regulations. Any pedestals to be located in
the public rights-of-way require written approval from the city. All such
equipment shall be shown on the design plans for permits.
(c)   Permits. Prior to construction or alteration, the franchisee shall,
consistent with the requirements of the franchise, file plans in each case with
the appropriate city agencies, enter into use agreements with the utility
companies, obtain all construction permits and receive written approval of the
city before proceeding.
(d)   Construction notice. The franchisee shall give appropriate notice in a
timely manner to the city and residents of proposed construction, excavation,
laying or stringing of cable under streets or on poles, but in no event shall
such notice be given less than 48 hours before such commencement.
(e)   Interference with persons, improvements, public and private property and
utilities. The franchisee's cable system and system facilities, including
poles, lines, equipment and all appurtenances, shall be located, erected and
maintained so that such facilities shall:
(1)   Not endanger or interfere with the health, safety or lives of persons;
(2)   Not unreasonably interfere with any improvements the city, county or
state may deem proper to make;
(3)   Not interfere with the free and proper use of public streets, alleys,
bridges, easements or other public ways, places or property; except to the
minimum extent possible during actual construction or repair;
(4)   Not interfere with the rights and reasonable convenience of private
property owners, except to the minimum extent possible during actual
construction or repair; and
(5)   Not obstruct, hinder or interfere with any gas, electric, water or
telephone facilities or other utilities located within the city.
(f)   Restoration to prior condition. In case of any disturbance of pavement,
sidewalk, driveway or other surfacing, the franchisee shall, at its own cost
and expense and in a manner approved by the city, replace and restore all
paving, sidewalk, driveway, landscaping, or surface of any street or alley
disturbed, in as good a condition as, or better than, before said work was
commenced and in a good workmanlike, timely manner in accordance with standards
for such work set by the city. Such restoration shall be commenced within no
more than 15 business days after the damage occurred and shall be completed as
soon as possible thereafter.
(g)   Disconnection and relocation. The franchisee shall, at its sole cost and
expense, protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in the same street,
or other streets and public grounds, or remove from any street or any other
public ways and places, and of its property as reason of traffic conditions,
public safety, street construction, change or establishment of street grade, or
the construction of any public improvement or structure by any city department.
(h)   Private property. The franchisee shall be subject to all laws and
regulations regarding private property or regulations regarding private
property in the course of constructing, installing, operating or maintaining
the cable system in the city. The franchisee shall promptly repair or replace
all private property, both real and personal, damaged or destroyed as a result
of the construction, installation, operating or maintenance of the cable system
at its sole cost and expense.
(i)   Cooperation with building movers. The franchisee shall, on the request of
any person holding a building moving permit issued by the city, temporarily
raise or lower its wire to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such
temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person
requesting the same, and the franchisee shall have the authority to require
such payment in advance. The franchisee shall be given not less than 15 working
days advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes.
(j)   Tree trimming. The franchisee may trim trees or other vegetation which is
located on property owned, leased or regulated by the city to prevent branches,
leaves or roots from touching or otherwise interfering with its wires, cables,
or other structures upon receiving prior written approval of the city. All
tree/root trimming or pruning provided for herewith shall be done under the
supervision and direction of the appropriate city agency. All trimming or
pruning requested by the franchisee shall be at the expense of the franchisee.
The franchisee may contract for such trimming or pruning services with any
person approved by the city prior to rendering of such services.
Any and all persons engaged by the franchisee to provide tree trimming or
pruning services shall be deemed, for purposes of the franchise, an employee or
agent of the franchisee when engaged in such activity and in no event shall
such person be deemed to be an employee of the city.
The franchisee shall use reasonable efforts to obtain the prior permission of
the owner of any privately owned trees or other vegetation before it prunes or
trims same.
Unless a shorter or longer time period is required by any other city ordinance,
the franchisee shall give appropriate notice to the city and residents within a
reasonable time of proposed tree/root trimming and pruning to be conducted by
the franchisee (or its designee), but in no event shall such notice be given
less than seven days before such commencement.
(k)   Public property. In addition to, and consistent with the requirements set
forth in other provisions of this chapter and the franchise, the franchisee
shall, prior to performing any underground construction, receive city and other
governmental approval to construct and the franchisee shall use its best
efforts to locate, in advance, any water, sewage, and drainage lines. Where any
damages or alterations occur to the city's water, sewage or drainage lines or
to any other city structures in the streets during the construction due to the
presence, negligence, operation or maintenance of the cable system, the sole
cost of such repairs including all services and materials will be billed
against the franchisee and these charges shall be paid promptly upon notice to
the franchisee.
(l)   Easements. All necessary easements over and under private property shall
be arranged for by the franchisee.
(m)   Construction and installation manual. If the franchisee has its own
construction and installation manual, the franchisee shall make available for
review by the city the manual which sets forth the specifications, standards
and procedures for construction and installation of its cable system. Said
manual shall be consistent with the prevailing standards of the top ten
multiple system operators in the cable industry and shall, at a minimum,
establish procedures to ensure quality work and provide for the safety and
protection of residents and property.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 18, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-49. Erection, removal and common use of poles.
(a)   Approval for poles. No poles shall be erected by the franchisee in the
public rights-of-way or on property owned or leased by the city without prior
approval of the city with regard to location, height, types and any other
pertinent aspect. However, no location of any pole or wire-holding structure of
the franchisee in the public rights-of- way or on property owned or leased by
the city shall give rise to a vested interest and such poles or wire-holding
structures shall be removed or modified by the franchisee at its own expense
upon 45 days written notice from the city to the franchisee (absent emergency
situations) whenever the city determines that the public convenience would be
enhanced thereby.
(b)   Use of existing poles. Where poles already exist for use in the city and
are available for use by the franchisee, the franchisee shall use such poles
and structures provided the franchisee determines that the terms of the use
available to the franchisee are just and reasonable, and provided such use is
consistent with the franchisee's technical and operational requirements for its
cable system.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 19, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-50. Conduit.
(a)   Approval for conduit. No conduit or related structures shall be installed
by the franchisee in the public rights-of-way or on property owned or leased by
the city without prior approval of the city with regard to location and any
other pertinent aspect. However, no location of any conduit or related
structures of the franchisee in the public rights-of-way or on property owned
or leased by the city shall give rise to a vested interest. Such conduit or
related structures shall be removed or modified by the franchisee at its own
expense upon 45 days written notice from the city to the franchisee (absent
emergency situations) whenever the city determines that the general health;
safety or welfare would be enhanced thereby.
(b)   Use of existing conduit. Where conduit already exists for use in the city
and is available for use by the franchisee, the franchisee shall use such
conduit provided the franchisee determines that the terms of the use available
to the franchisee are just and reasonable, and provided such use is consistent
with the franchisee's technical and operational requirements for its cable
system.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 20, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-51. Tests and performance monitoring.
(a)   Completion tests. Not later than 60 days after any new or substantially
rebuilt portion of the cable system is made available for service to
subscribers, and thereafter semi-annually pursuant to the FCC's technical
standards during the term of the franchise, the franchisee shall conduct
technical performance tests to demonstrate full compliance with the technical
standards and guidelines of the FCC or other applicable governmental authority.
(b)   Methodology. Such tests shall be performed by, or under the supervision
of a qualified registered professional engineer. Upon request of the city, a
copy of the report shall be submitted to the city, describing test results,
instrumentation, calibration, and test procedures, and the qualification of the
engineer responsible for the tests.
(c)   Test points. System monitor test points shall be established pursuant to
the FCC technical standards.
(d)   Regulatory tests. In addition to the performance test reports required
herein, a copy of any performance test reports required by the FCC or other
governmental authority shall be submitted to the city within ten days of the
city's request.
(e)   City required tests. Whenever there have been repeated or multiple
complaints made or when there exists other relevant evidence, which would
reasonably cast doubt on the compliance of the franchisee's cable system or
system facilities with applicable standards, the city shall notify the
franchisee in writing of any deficiencies and may require the franchisee to
test, analyze, and report on the performance of its system at the expense of
the franchisee. In the event any deficiencies are not corrected, the city may
require additional tests, full or partial repeat tests, different test
procedures, or tests involving a specific subscriber's terminal at the expense
of the franchisee. Tests shall be conducted within a reasonable time after
requested but not later than 30 days unless mutually agreed upon by the parties
hereto. Reports on such tests shall be delivered to the city no later than 14
days after completion of the tests. The report shall include the following
information: a summary of the reasons for conducting the tests; the cable
system component tested; the procedures employed in said testing; the results
of such tests; and methods by which any complaints were resolved. Said tests
and analyses shall be supervised by a qualified engineer who shall sign all
records of the special tests and forward same to the city with a report
interpreting the results of the tests and recommending what actions should be
taken. If requested by the city, the franchisee shall retain an independent
engineer to conduct such tests. All such tests by an independent engineer shall
be at the expense of the city unless the test results confirm the presence of
material noncompliance with applicable standards and, in that event, the
franchisee shall pay all costs, fees and expenses of the independent engineer.
(f)   General maintenance. The franchisee shall maintain wires, cables and all
other real and personal property and facilities constituting the cable system
in good condition, order and repair at all times during the term of the
franchise.
(g)   Maintenance log. The franchisee shall maintain an annual log showing the
date, approximate time and duration, type and probable cause of all cable
system outages, whole or partial, due to causes other than routine testing or
maintenance. The entries in such log shall be retained by the franchisee for
one additional year and shall be subject to inspection and copying by the city
or its designee during the franchisee's regular business hours upon reasonable
request.
(h)   Service interruption. Except where there exists an emergency situation
necessitating a more expeditious procedure, the franchisee shall use reasonable
efforts to schedule planned service interruptions for the purpose of repairing,
upgrading or testing the cable system, only during periods of minimum use, and
after using reasonable efforts to notify affected subscribers.
(Ord. No 2496, § 21, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-52. City's right to perform public works.
Nothing in this chapter shall be in hindrance to the right of the city or any
governmental authority to perform or carry on, directly or indirectly, any
public works or public improvements of any description. Should the cable system
in any way interfere with the construction, maintenance or repair of such
public works or public improvements, the franchisee shall, at its own cost and
expense, protect or relocate its cable system, or part thereof, as reasonably
directed by the city officials or any governmental authority.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 22, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-53. Emergency removal of plant.
If at any time, in case of fire or disaster in the city, it shall become
necessary in the reasonable judgment of the city to cut or move any of the
wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances or appurtenances of the cable system, the
city shall have the right to do so at the sole cost and expense of the
franchisee provided that the city provides prior written notice of such
activity. If under the circumstances prior written notice is not possible, the
city shall provide the franchisee with notice as soon as is possible. The
franchisee shall bear all costs of reinstallation, repair, and other costs
resulting from or arising out of the emergency cutting or removal of the cable
system.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 23, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-54. Removal or abandonment.
Upon termination or revocation of the franchise by passage of time or
otherwise, and unless the franchisee transfers the cable system to a subsequent
franchisee approved by the city, the franchisee shall remove its supporting
structures, poles, transmission and distribution systems; and all other
appurtenances from the public rights-of-way and from any city property and
shall restore any property, public or private, to the same or similar condition
as they existed prior to the installation, erection, or construction of the
cable system. Restoration of the public rights-of-way and of city property
shall be in accordance with the directions and specifications of all affected
departments and agencies of the city, and all applicable laws and regulations.
The franchisee, at the option and direction of the city, shall accomplish such
restoration at its expense. Such removal shall be made with the supervision of
the city. If such removal and restoration is not completed within 12 months
after the notice by the city delivered in writing to the franchisee all of the
franchisee's property remaining in the affected public rights-of-way shall, at
the option of the city, shall be deemed abandoned and shall, at the option of
the city, become the property of the city. In the event the franchisee fails or
refuses to remove its cable system or satisfactorily restore all areas to the
condition in which they existed prior to the original construction of the cable
system, the city, at its option, may perform such work and collect the cost
thereof from the franchisee. No surety on any bond nor any letter of credit
shall be discharged until the city has certified to the franchisee in writing
that the cable system has been dismantled, removed, and all other property,
city property and public rights-of-way restored to the satisfaction of the
city.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 24, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-55. Time is of the essence.
Whenever this chapter shall set forth any time for any act to be performed by
or on behalf of the franchisee, such time shall be deemed to be of the essence.
Any failure of the franchisee to perform within the time allotted shall be
sufficient ground for the city to invoke an appropriate penalty including
possible termination or revocation of the franchise, following applicable
notices of default and cure procedures provided for in this chapter.
(Ord No. 2496, § 25, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-56. No waiver of rights.
No course of dealing between the franchisee and the city nor any delay on the
part of the city in exercising any rights hereunder shall operate as a waiver
of any such rights of the city or acquiescence in the actions of the franchisee
in contravention of rights except to the extent expressly waived by the city or
expressly provided for in the franchise.
(Ord. No. 2496, § 26, 6-23-98)
Sec. 4.5-57. Transfer.
(a)   Franchise. A franchise shall not be assigned or transferred, either in
whole or in part, or leased, sublet, or mortgaged in any manner, nor shall
title to the cable system, legal or equitable, or any right, interest or
properly therein, pass to or vest in any person without the prior written
consent of the city.
(b)   Ownership. The franchisee shall not sell, transfer or dispose of ten
