ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 13-1. Chief executive officer.
The chief of police, subject to the control of the city manager, shall be the
chief executive officer of the police department and shall have general
supervision and control of all police officers and the department in general.
(Code 1965, § 21-2)
Charter reference(s)—General duties of city manager, § 24.
Sec. 13-2. Investigation and report of accidents for which city may be liable.
The chief of police, immediately upon the happening of any accident which may
result in injury to person or property within the city, for which the city may
be held liable, shall make or cause to be made a thorough investigation of the
circumstances surrounding such accident and shall forthwith report, in writing,
to the corporation counsel the following:
(1)   The names of the parties or location of the property injured;
(2)   The names of the witnesses to the injury and their places of residence;
(3)   The substance of any statement that he is able to obtain from each one of
them;
(4)   The place of the accident;
(5)   The cause in his opinion of such accident;
(6)   The date thereof; and
(7)   Any other information which may throw light thereon.
(Code 1965, § 21-5)
State law reference(s)—Reports and investigations required in event of
collision, G.S. 20-166.1.
Secs. 13-3—13-5. Reserved.
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 4910, § 2, adopted November 9, 2021, repealed § 13-3,
which pertained to disposition of stolen property; hospital reports upon
receipt of certain patients; and reporting of accidental or violent deaths to
police and medical examiner, and derived from the Code of 1965, §§ 21-6—21-8.
Sec. 13-6. Police reserve unit.
(a)   Creation. There is hereby created within the police department a police
reserve unit, each member of which shall be appointed by the chief of police.
Each such member shall serve so long as the chief of police shall direct or
until such member submits his resignation. Members of such unit shall assist
and aid the regular police of the city.
(b)   Composition; qualifications of members. The police reserve unit shall be
composed of police reserves in a number not to exceed 30 qualified volunteers.
Such volunteers shall be not less than 21 years of age at the time of their
appointment and shall have such other qualifications as the chief of police may
determine. At the discretion of the chief, a screening board may be created to
determine such qualifications.
(c)   Powers and duties. The police reserve unit members shall have full police
powers while on duty or while under the control and direction of the chief of
police. Its members shall perform only such police duties as may be assigned by
the chief of police and then only when dressed or uniformed as prescribed by
the chief, and shall be available for any departmental emergencies as the chief
of police may determine. Such duties shall be performed only within the
corporate limits or on property outside the city limits which is owned by the
city.
(d)   Regulations; records; supervision; disciplinary action. The chief of
police shall prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct, control and
administration of the police reserve unit. Each reserve member's record shall
be subject to inspection and review for approval at six-month intervals by the
chief of police. Members of the police reserve unit shall obey all lawful
orders of any members of the police department. Within the police reserve unit
there shall be a reserve leader of such unit who, subject to the orders and
control of the chief, shall exercise supervision of the police reserve unit.
Such reserve leader shall be appointed by the chief of police. All disciplinary
action shall be for cause, shall require notice and hearing and shall be
administered by the chief of police.
(e)   Uniforms and equipment. The chief of police shall prescribe the uniform
to be worn by the members of the police reserve unit. The city shall provide
uniforms and such equipment as the chief may deem necessary and proper.
(f)   Oath; bond; benefits. Each member of the police reserve unit shall take
the same oath as other police officers and shall be covered by the same bond
as, shall have the same privileges and immunities of and shall be entitled to
the same benefits as regularly employed police officers, including but not
limited to benefits under the state workers' compensation act.
(Code 1965, § 21-11)
Charter reference(s)—Appointment of special police authorized,§ 38A.
Secs. 13-7—13-30. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR POLICE ALARMS 2
 
Notes
  Editor's note(s)—
  Ord. No. 4384, § 1, adopted June 22, 2021, repealed Art. II, §§ 13-31—13-39,
  which pertained to alarm systems and enacted provisions designated as a new Art.
  II to read as herein set out and derived from Ord. No. 2951, § 1, adopted Aug.
  29, 2002.
2 Cross reference(s)—
  Licenses, permits and business regulations,
  ch. 9
  ; subdivisions,
  ch. 17
  .
Sec. 13-31. Definitions.
Alarm means any electronic or mechanical device which emits any signal
(electronic, visible, audible, silent, recorded or otherwise), which is
designed, intended, or used to detect unauthorized entry into a building,
structure, or premises, to signal an attempted robbery or holdup, or the
commission of an unlawful act in or around a building, structure, or premises
that is intended to elicit a response by the police.
Alarm administrator means a person, persons, firm, partnership, association or
corporation designated by the City of Asheville's chief of police to administer
the provisions of this ordinance.
Alarm business means any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation
subject to Chapter 74D of the North Carolina General Statutes engaged in
selling, leasing, installing, servicing or monitoring of alarms.
Alarm systems coordinator (herein "ASC") means an employee of the City of
Asheville or its alarm administrator designated by the chief of police to
administer this article.
Alarm permit means a permit issued to an alarm user by the City of Asheville
and/or its alarm administrator allowing the operation of an alarm system within
the city.
Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including, but not limited
to, hardwired systems and systems interconnected with a radio frequency method
such as cellular, private radio signals, or internet, which emit or transmit a
remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm
condition and intended to summon a city emergency service response, including
local alarm systems. Alarm system does not include an alarm installed in a
vehicle or on someone's person unless the vehicle or the personal alarm is
permanently located at a site.
Alarm user means any person, corporation, partnership, governmental or
educational entity owning, leasing, or occupying a property utilizing an alarm.
Asheville Police Department (herein "APD") means a department of the city or
its consolidated call center that receives telephone or signal requests for
police, fire, ambulance, rescue, or other emergency service within the city.
Automatic dial protection device means an automatic dialing device, automatic
telephone dialing alarm system or any system which, upon being activated,
automatically initiates a recorded message or code signal indicating a need for
an emergency response.
Cancellation means termination of response by an emergency service when the
alarm company notifies the responding agency or department that there is not an
existing situation at the alarm site requiring police response after an alarm
dispatch request. If cancellation occurs prior to police arriving at the scene,
this is not a false alarm and no penalty will be assessed.
Compliance Standards means equipment and installation methods shall comply with
all appropriate nationally recognized testing laboratories and American
National Standards Institute (ANSI) requirements.
Enhanced call confirmation (ECC), means an attempt by the alarm system
monitoring company to contact the alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone
and/or other means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, to
determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement
response. A second call shall be made to an alternate number provided by the
alarm user if the first attempt fails. EXCEPT in case of a fire, panic or
robbery-in-progress alarm or in cases where a crime-in-progress has been
verified as defined in ANSI/CSAA CS-V-01-2016 or an equivalent standard.
False alarm means activation of an alarm by any means that elicits a response
by a city emergency service when no situation requiring such a response does,
in fact, exist. This includes accidental, avoidable, and unnecessary alarm
activation due to user error, equipment malfunction, improper or unsuited
equipment, but does not include alarm activation caused by violent conditions
of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to
control by the alarm user or alarm business.
False alarm day means any 24-hour period that begins with the occurrence of a
false alarm.
Local audible alarm means any alarm owned by an alarm user that, by sound of a
whistle, bell, buzzer, siren or other noise generator, alerts those outside the
home or building, of a break-in or robbery, but does not transmit a signal by
telephone or other communications device.
Local alarm means an alarm system that emits a signal at an alarm site that is
audible or visible from the exterior of a structure and is not monitored by a
remote monitoring facility, whether installed by an alarm company or user.
Permit year means a 12-month period beginning on the day and month on which an
alarm permit is issued.
Police chief means the chief of police for the City of Asheville or his/her
designee.
Runaway alarm means an alarm system that produces three or more unfounded alarm
signals in a 24 hour period. City emergency services may, at their discretion,
discontinue responding to these alarm signals until the alarm system is
corrected.
Registered alarm means an alarm that has been listed with the Asheville Police
Department or its designee in accordance with the application and permitting
requirements of this article.
Verify means an attempt by the alarm system monitoring company to contact the
alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone and/or other electronic means,
regardless of whether actual contact with a person is made, to determine
whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement response. A
second call shall be made to an alternate number provided by the alarm user if
the first attempt fails.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-32. Requirements for alarm users.
(a)   Permit and application.
(1)   Every alarm user shall obtain a permit for each alarm that operates
within the city from the alarm system coordinator (herein "ASC"). An alarm
business must obtain a permit under this section only if an alarm is used to
protect the premises in which the business is located. The ASC will provide the
permit application form. No other permit application form will be accepted.
(2)   All alarm businesses doing business in the city shall provide the ASC a
current copy of its license pursuant to Chapter 74D of the North Carolina
General Statutes and the contact person's name, address and telephone number
for the alarm business.
(3)   A permit application shall be submitted within 30 days of installation of
an alarm system. The ASC shall approve such application if the application
complies with the provisions set forth in this article. During this 30-day
period, the alarm user will not be subject to the provisions of section
13-32(e)(1).
(4)   The person applying for the permit at the time of application shall pay
the application set forth in the city's fees and charges manual.
(5)   When possession and/or control of a premises with an alarm is
transferred, the person obtaining possession and/or control of the premises is
required to file an application for a new alarm permit within ten business days
of obtaining possession of the property. Permits are not transferable.
(6)   Whenever the information provided on the permit application changes, the
alarm user must notify the ASC within 30 days of the change. In addition, on an
annual basis, after the issuance of the permit, the alarm user will receive
from the ASC a form requesting updated information. The permit holder shall
complete and return this form to the ASC.
(7)   In the interest of public safety, all information contained in and
gathered through the alarm permit application(s) and application(s) shall not
be considered public records per N.C.G.S. § 132-1.7 and other applicable law.
(b)   Denial and revocation.
(1)   The ASC may revoke a permit where it is found that the alarm user
provided false information on the permit application.
(2)   The ASC may revoke a permit if the alarm user does not respond to an
alarm activation as required in section
13-34.
(3)   The ASC may revoke a permit if the alarm user fails to comply with the
provisions in this article.
(c)   Permit required. Each permit for a business shall be available at the
premises wherein the alarm is installed and shall be available for inspection
by the police chief during normal business hours.
(d)   Multiple systems. If an alarm user has one or more alarm systems
protecting two or more separate structures having different addresses and/or
tenants, a separate permit shall be required for each structure and/or tenant.
(e)   Failure to obtain a permit.
(1)   Any alarm user who operates an alarm without a permit or who has not
applied for a permit under this section as required by this article shall be
assessed a civil penalty of as stated below:
a.   First alarm to which police respond—$0.00 (a warning will be issued and
the alarm holder will have ten working days to secure a permit).
b.   Second and subsequent alarms to which police respond—$100.00 per
occurrence.
(2)   The above civil penalty is in addition to those civil penalties listed in
section
13-37(b).
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-33. Automatic dialing protection devices prohibited.
No automatic dial protection device shall be used to report, or cause to be
reported, any recorded message to the APD. Police will not respond to recorded
messages.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-34. Alarm user response to alarms.
(a)   The alarm user, or a representative thereof, shall be available at all
times for the purpose of responding to alarms by personally appearing at the
structure designated in the permit following an alarm activation.
(b)   If, in the event of any alarm, the APD or other agency is unable to
notify the alarm user or a representative thereof or if the alarm user or a
representative thereof fails to appear at the home or structure designated in
the permit within 30 minutes after notification, the permit may be revoked.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-35. False alarms.
(a)   Whenever an alarm is activated in the city and the APD responds, a police
officer on the scene of the activated alarm system shall inspect the area and
determine whether the police response was in fact necessary as indicated by the
alarm system or whether the alarm was a false alarm.
(b)   If the police officer at the scene of the activated alarm system
determines the alarm to be false, the alarm user shall be notified.
(c)   The ASC may require the inspection of an alarm system for which there
have been five false alarm days within a twelve-month period. A representative
of an alarm business selected by the alarm user must perform the inspection.
Any cost associated with the inspection will be beared by the alarm user. The
ASC must have proof of the inspection within 30 days after the alarm user
receives notice. Failure to provide proof of inspection may result in
revocation of the alarm permit.
(d)   All local audible alarms shall be equipped with an automatic reset device
that will reset and cease to sound the alarm after 15 minutes of continuous
activation. The alarm user shall be assessed an additional civil penalty of
$50.00 for each violation of a continuing local audible alarm activation. This
penalty is in addition to any false alarm penalty as set forth in section
13-37.
(e)   Signals or messages transmitted by the alarm during alarm testing
procedures shall not be considered false alarms provided the APD is notified of
the testing and the APD does not respond.
(f)   It shall be unlawful to activate an alarm system for the purpose of
summoning law enforcement when no burglary, robbery, or other crime dangerous
to life or property is being committed or attempted on the premises, or
otherwise to cause a false alarm.
(g)   The city may discontinue response of city emergency services if the city
determines that:
(1)   There is any violation of this article
(2)   There is a false statement of material matter in the application of
permit.
(3)   An alarm system has generated in excess of ten false alarms during any
twelve-month period.
(4)   The alarm holder has failed to make payment of any service fee, permit
fee, late fee or suspension fee assessed under this article within 90 days of
the assessment.
(h)   Reinstatement of response: the city may resume city emergency services
response upon the alarm holder submitting satisfactory proof of compliance of
one or more of the following:
(1)   Proof the alarm system has been inspected and the city has been provided
evidence of adequate measures to ensure the alarm system is in good working
order. Measures taken may require the alarm user repair, upgrade or modify the
alarm system to be compliant with this chapter.
(2)   Proof the alarm user has been retrained on the use of the alarm system
and procedures for contacting the alarm company in the case of false
activation.
(3)   The alarm user successfully completes an on-line alarm awareness class
and test.
(4)   All fees and fines are paid in full including the reinstatement fee of
$50.00.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-36. Review of false alarm determinations.
   The ASC shall, when requested by an alarm user, review the determination
that an alarm was false. The ASC shall conduct such review only if the alarm
user requests in writing such a review within ten days of the date that the
false alarm occurred. The written request for review of a false alarm
determination by the ASC shall include the following information:
(1)   Alarm user name;
(2)   Address where alarm is installed;
(3)   Date of contested false alarm;
(4)   Alarm user permit number;
(5)   Factual basis for review request.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-37. Service charge assessment for false alarms and reinstatement of
alarm user permits.
(a)   Three or more false alarm days within any twelve-month period is
excessive and constitutes a public nuisance.
(b)   Civil penalties. The alarm user shall be assessed the following civil
penalties based on the number of false alarm days in one year. The civil
penalties are as follows:
 
3—5 false alarm days    $50.00
6th false alarm           $100.00
7th false alarm           $100.00
8th false alarm           $250.00
9th false alarm           $250.00
10th and over false alarm $500.00
 
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-38. Appeal.
(a)   Any alarm user assessed a civil penalty or whose application for a permit
has been denied, or whose permit has been revoked under this article may
request, in writing, a hearing with the police chief. In such a case, the
notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed in the police chief's office
within ten days of the issuance of a final decision by the ASC. The police
chief, or designee, shall schedule a hearing on the matter within a reasonable
time from the date the notice of appeal is filed.
(b)   Failure to perfect an appeal within the time and in the manner provided
for in this section shall constitute a waiver of the right to appeal.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-39. Notice and hearing.
Before the ASC revokes a permit pursuant to this article, or if an appeal is
taken pursuant to section
13-32 from a decision of the ASC denying an application for a permit, the ASC
shall cause a written notice to be sent by first class mail, return postage
guaranteed, to the permittee or applicant affected, at the address stated on
the permit or application 30 days in advance of revocation or denial. This
notice shall advise the affected party of a right to appear before the police
chief, with or without legal counsel, at a stated time and place, for the
purpose of presenting any evidence relevant to such revocation or denial, or
for the purpose of hearing all evidence submitted and examine or cross-
examining any person providing such evidence. The decision of the police chief
shall be final. An administrative fee for each appeal to the police chief, in
an amount set out in the city's fees and charges manual, will be assessed.
Should the appeal be successful, the administrative fee shall be reimbursed to
the alarm user.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-40 Fee schedule.
Fee schedule set forth in the city's fees and charges manual.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Sec. 13-41 Alarm business duties.
(a)   Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation engaged in the
alarm business in the City of Asheville shall comply with the following:
(1)   Obtain and maintain the required state, county and/or city license(s).
(2)   Provide name, address, and telephone numbers of the alarm company license
holder or a designee who can be called in an emergency, 24 hours a day; and be
able to respond to an alarm call, when notified, within a reasonable amount of
time.
(3)   Be able to provide the most current contact information for the alarm
user; and to contact a key holder for a response, if requested.
(4)   Provide new and cancelled alarm sites in the format required by the city
every 30 days or upon request by the city.
(b)   An alarm installation company and/or monitoring company that purchases
alarm system accounts from another person shall notify the city of such
purchase and provide details as may be requested by the city.
(1)   Prior to activation of the alarm system, the alarm company must provide
instructions explaining the proper operation of the alarm system to the alarm
user. Ensure that all alarm users of alarm systems equipped with a duress,
holdup or panic alarm are given adequate training as to the proper use of the
duress, holdup or panic alarm.
(2)   After completion of the installation of an alarm system, the alarm
company employee shall review with the alarm user the customer false alarm
prevention checklist approved by the city or its designated administrator. The
alarm company employee shall complete, sign and date the alarm prevention
checklist and maintain a copy for a period of two years.
(3)   An alarm company performing monitoring services shall:
a.   Attempt to confirm, by calling the alarm site and/or alarm user by
telephone, to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting
dispatch. Telephone confirmation shall require, as a minimum, that a second
call also known as Enhanced Call Confirmation (ECC), be made to a different
number, if the first attempt fails to reach an alarm user who can properly
identify themselves to attempt to determine whether an alarm signal is valid,
EXCEPT in case of a fire, panic or robbery-in-progress alarm or in cases where
a crime-in-progress has been verified as defined in ANSI/CSAA CS-V-01-2016 or
an equivalent standard.
b.   Provide alarm user registration number to facilitate dispatch and/or
cancellations.
c.   Communicate any available information about the location of the alarm.
d.   Communicate a cancellation as soon as possible following a determination
that response is unnecessary.
(c)   Maintain for a period of at least one year from the date of the alarm
dispatch request, records relating to the alarm dispatch. Records must include
name, address and telephone number of the alarm user, the alarm system zones
activated, the time of alarm dispatch request and evidence of an attempt to
verify the alarm. The alarm administrator may request copies of such records
for individually named alarm users. If the request is made, the alarm
monitoring company shall provide requested information within ten business days
of receiving the request.
(Ord. No. 4384, § 1, 6-22-2021)
Secs. 13-42—13-59. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. ABC PERMIT
Sec. 13-60. Police authority regarding criminal history information for
applicants for ABC permits.
The police department shall be authorized to seek state access to SBI/DCI
Criminal History Record Information to obtain criminal history information on
all persons applying for ABC permits for proposed locations within the city.
(Ord. No. 3640, § 1, 7-22-08)
Chapter 15 SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT  1

Sec. 15-1. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
Biodegradable paper yard waste bags. A bag that is designated for the use of
yard waste containment and is biodegradable such that it can be processed and/
or composted with the brush trimmings and/or leaves which it contains.
Brush trimmings. Waste accumulation of tree branches, tree limbs, bushes,
shrubbery, cuttings or clippings usually created as refuse in the trimming or
cutting of trees, shrubs or bushes, including parts of trees. Grass clippings
are not included in brush trimmings, and shall not be collected by the city.
Brush trimmings containers. Biodegradable paper yard waste bags or personal
reusable brush containers in a serviceable condition which, when full, do not
weigh more than 50 pounds, except paper bags, which shall not weigh more than
25 pounds when full.
Building materials. Any material such as lumber, brick, block, stone, plaster,
concrete, asphalt, roofing shingles, gutters or other substances accumulated as
the result of repairs or additions to existing buildings or structures,
construction of new buildings or structures or the demolition of existing
buildings or structures.
Bulk container. A metal container of not less than two cubic yards capacity nor
larger than eight cubic yards capacity, constructed to be watertight but with
drain plugs at the lowest point of the container to facilitate the drainage of
any liquids that might accumulate in the container or from cleaning the
container. Bulk containers shall have doors that open on the top. Bulk
containers shall be designed so that they can be emptied mechanically by
specially designed trucks.
Business trash. Any waste accumulation of dust, paper, cardboard, excelsior,
rags or other accumulations other than garbage or household trash which are
usually attendant to the operation of stores, offices and similar businesses.
City. The City of Asheville, North Carolina.
Collection facility. A center located for the purpose of accepting by donation,
redemption, or purchase, recyclable materials from the public.
Commercial establishment. Any retail, wholesale, institutional, religious,
governmental or other establishment or hotel, exclusive of residences, which
may generate garbage, business trash or other refuse.
Corrugated cardboard. Any packaging board consisting of but not confined to
craft paper with fluted or wavy middle layer and having one or more flat outer
walls.
Debris. The remains of something broken down or destroyed.
Detachable container. A container unit that may vary in capacity between 15
cubic yards and 42 cubic yards and which is used for collecting, storing and
transporting waste building materials, business trash, industrial waste,
hazardous refuse, leaves, or brush. The unit may or may not use an auxiliary
packing mechanism for the compaction of the materials into the container and
may be of the open or the enclosed type. The distinguishing feature of the
detachable container is that it is lifted by a specially designed and equipped
truck and becomes an integral part of that truck for transporting waste
materials to a disposal site.
Garbage. The waste produced by the handling, processing, preparation, cooking
and consumption of animal or vegetable products used for human consumption.
This definition shall include any other matter that is also subject to
decomposition, decay, putrefaction or the generation of noxious or offensive
gases or odors or which before, during or after decay may serve as feeding or
breeding material for animals or flies or other insects.
Household customer. A single residential unit located within the jurisdiction
of the city that participates in the city's solid waste collection program.
Hazardous refuse. Materials such as poisons, acids, caustics, harmful or
dangerous chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, explosives,
highly flammable material and parts of the human anatomy including pathological
specimens.
Household trash. Waste accumulation of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles,
cans or other waste material of any kind, other than garbage, which is
attendant to residential housekeeping.
Industrial waste. All waste, including solids, semisolids, sludge and liquids,
created or generated by factories, processing plants or other manufacturing
enterprises.
Leaf or leaves. The foliage of trees. Grass clippings are not included in the
definition of leaves and shall not be collected by the city.
Litter. Any rubbish, waste material, cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead
animals or discarded materials of every kind and description not handled or
disposed of as set forth in this chapter.
Loading and unloading area. Any space or area used by any moving vehicle for
the purpose of receiving, shipping and transporting goods, wares, commodities
and persons.
Multiple residential complexes. A single residential unit consisting of any
duplex, triplex, quadraplex or apartment used as a dwelling place.
Municipal solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the operation of residential,
commercial, industrial, governmental, or institutional establishments that
would normally be collected, processed, and disposed of through a public or
private solid waste management service. Municipal solid waste does not include
hazardous waste, sludge, or solid waste from mining or agricultural operations.
Parking lot. Any area, paved or unpaved, the principal function of which is the
parking of six or more motor vehicles. This definition excludes those parking
spaces on public streets.
Portable packing unit. A metal container that contains a packing mechanism with
an internal or external power unit.
Public works director. The person appointed by the city manager to be in charge
of the operations of the City of Asheville Public Works Department.
Recyclable materials. Includes, but is not limited to, clear, green, and brown
container glass, aluminum cans, steel food cans, no. 1 and no. 2 plastic
containers, newsprint and inserts, and corrugated cardboard.
Recycling. The process by which recovered resources are transformed into new
products in such a manner as the original products lose their identity.
Recycling receptacle. Any container for the purpose of serving for the
collection of recyclable materials.
Refuse. Solid waste accumulations consisting of garbage, household trash, and
business trash.
Refuse receptacle. means any of the following:
Automated roll-out container. A specialized container owned by the City of
Asheville designed specifically for use with the automated refuse collection
vehicles and supplied to residents specifically for collection of municipal
solid waste.
Roll-out container. A plastic container of substantial construction having a
capacity of not less than 80 gallons or more than 100 gallons, containing a
hinged lid, designed to be emptied mechanically by specially designed lift
devices attached to city sanitation trucks.
Hand-emptied container. A metal or plastic container of substantial
construction with a tight fitting lid which shall be provided with wheels and
handles for safe and convenient handling. Such receptacle shall have a capacity
of not less than ten gallons or more than 32 gallons. Such container shall
weigh no more than 50 pounds when full.
Polyethylene plastic bag. A polyethylene plastic bag that shall weigh no more
than 25 pounds when full. Such bag may be used only where dogs, rodents or
other animals are not a cause of litter. Use of plastic bags is subject to the
approval of the solid waste manager.
Cardboard boxes. Cardboard boxes, cartons or crates that may be used only to
contain other cardboard boxes, cartons or crates and that must be properly
secured by tying or taping. Such cardboard boxes shall not exceed a dimension
of five feet by six feet by three feet and shall have a volume of at least
eight cubic feet. Such boxes shall not exceed a weight of 50 pounds when full.
Such boxes shall have a one-time use and shall be collected along with the
refuse contained in them.
Reusable brush container. Any rigid plastic container used for yard waste
containment, or other reusable yard waste storage device as approved in writing
by the solid waste manager. A reusable brush container shall have a capacity of
not less than 10 gallons or more than 32 gallons, shall weigh no more than 50
pounds when full, shall not accumulate rainwater, and shall be clearly marked
to designate contents as 'Brush' or 'Leaves'.
Residence. Any structure used as a dwelling place by a single family. A single
condominium shall be defined as a residence for purposes of this chapter.
Small dead animals. Cats, dogs, small household pets and other animals of
similar size.
Solid waste manager. The person designated by the public work director to
enforce and carry out the provisions of this chapter.
Trash. Includes business trash and household trash.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08; Ord. No. 4993, § 1, 1-10-23)
Sec. 15-2. Administration.
(a)   The public works director shall be charged with the duty and
responsibility of the administration of this chapter.
(b)   Fees. The city may establish and revise from time to time schedules of
rates, fees and charges for the use of automated containers over the one
automated container that has been provided under article II and for curbside
recycling under article III of this chapter. Fees and charges shall be set
forth in the city's Fees and Charges Manual and billed as set forth below:
(1)   All recycling charges, as described above shall be charged to the
customer's water bill. All payments and partial payments, received from the
customer in connection with the water billing statement, shall initially be
applied to the enterprise service for recycling; and
(2)   Secondly, charges will be applied as they pertain to the rented automated
containers; and
(3)   The city may discontinue service to any customer whose account remains
delinquent for more than ten days; and
(4)   In addition, the city has the option to pursue account delinquency in
accordance with N. C. Gen. Stat. 160A-314.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-3. Responsibility for compliance.
The owners or agents, tenants or lessees, jointly and separately, of all
residential units and commercial establishments shall be responsible for
compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-4. Litter, offensive odors, dangerous devices prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow unsightly litter, foul or
offensive odors or potentially dangerous devices to remain on or emanate from
any property under his control or to discard, abandon or cause such material on
any public or private property within the corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-5. Maintenance of sidewalks, alleys and rights-of-way.
All owners or occupants, jointly and separately, of property shall maintain
their property in a clean and litter- free manner, including adjacent
sidewalks, grass strips, one-half of alleys, curbs, gutters and rights-of-way
to the edge of the surface of the vehicular travel-way of any public street.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-6. Accumulations, removal of weeds, trash, refuse other material.
(a)   Accumulation prohibited. Every person who is the owner of land lying and
situated within the city or who occupies, rents or leases any such land shall
keep such land and all appurtenances thereto free and clear of all trash,
rubbish, garbage, weeds, grass or other objects that cause such land and
appurtenances to become a nuisance or menace to the health and welfare of the
citizens who live adjacent or near thereto.
(b)   Responsibility of owners and agents. It shall be the duty of the owner,
occupant or tenant of such land to keep the weeds, bushes, grass and any other
vegetation cut and removed from the land to the extent that the vegetation:
(1)   Will not afford a breeding place for flies, mosquitoes, rats or any other
rodents;
(2)   Is not a menace to the health and welfare of the people living on or near
such land; and
(3)   Such land shall not become a fire hazard or endanger the life or property
of others.
(c)   Failure to remove weeds, trash, garbage, grass or other materials. If the
owner, occupant or tenant of such land shall fail to remove such weeds, trash,
garbage, grass or other objects that cause such land to be a nuisance in the
city, the authorized city official charged with the responsibility of enforcing
this chapter, shall have the authority to assess a civil penalty against the
respective owner, occupant, or tenant under the provisions stated in this
chapter.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Secs. 15-7—15-35. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. STORAGE AND COLLECTION
Sec. 15-36. Receptacles and containers required.
(a)   Household customers/multiple residential complexes/commercial
establishments without city automated trash collection: Every person who is in
possession or control of any place in or from which business trash, garbage,
household trash or industrial waste is accumulated or produced shall be
required to provide, and at all times, keep receptacles and containers in a
suitable place. Such receptacles and containers should be readily accessible to
city collection crews or private collection agencies. City collection crews
will not remove any form of waste which is not readily accessible. Adequate and
suitable receptacles and containers capable of holding all specified waste
material, which would ordinarily accumulate between the times of successive
collections, are required. The solid waste manager is authorized to determine
the quantity, type and location of such receptacles or containers; as provided
in this chapter, and to determine whether such receptacles and containers are
serviceable and sanitary.
(b)   Household customers/multiple residential complexes/commercial
establishments with city automated trash collection: The solid waste manager,
subject to the final approval of the director of public works, is authorized to
determine if automated trash collection service is applicable to an individual
resident or business. Every person who is in possession or control of any place
in or for which business trash, garbage, household trash, or industrial waste
is accumulated or produced shall be provided, at no cost to the household, with
a specialized automated roll-out container designed specifically for use with
the automated trash collection truck. The specialized containers are the
property of the city and shall be left at the residence/business, should the
original owners move. The solid waste manager shall determine the location of
such containers as provided in this chapter. The resident/business may rent
additional containers over the one automated rollout container provided,
subject to the following terms:
(1)   The city may establish and revise from time to time schedules or rates,
fees and charges for the use/rental of automated containers over the one
automated container that has been provided. Fees and charges shall be set forth
in the city's Fees and Charges Manual.
(2)   All charges, as described in subsection (b), shall be charged each
billing period to the customer's water bill. Once the customer gives consent to
assess the aforesaid cost to the customer's water bill, all payments and
partial payments, received from the customer in connection with the water
billing statement, shall initially be applied to the automated container fee.
In lieu of placing the cost on the customer's water bill, the customer may
prepay for a period not less than 12 months. The customer has up to six months
from the date of prepayment to cancel the written request and receive a partial
refund. The city will not honor a refund, partial, or otherwise, after the
expiration of six months from the date of prepayment. The city may discontinue
service to any customer whose account remains delinquent for more than ten
days. In addition, the city has the option to pursue account delinquency in the
same manner as delinquent water accounts are collected.
(c)   It shall be unlawful for any resident to put household generated trash in
any street refuse receptacle or container maintained by the city. All residents
must use their own refuse containers for trash disposal. Any resident using
city owned street receptacles or containers for their private use shall be
deemed in violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-37. Construction and maintenance of refuse receptacles.
(a)   All refuse receptacles as required in this chapter shall be of safe
construction and design. Each refuse receptacle shall be maintained in a good,
serviceable and sanitary condition at all times. Any refuse receptacle which
does not conform to the provisions of this chapter, has ragged or sharp edges
or other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents,
or the public, shall, in most instances, be promptly replaced upon notice. If
such refuse receptacle, after due and proper notice, has not been replaced, the
solid waste manager may refuse to allow city employees to handle the refuse
receptacle until replaced.
(b)   All automated containers for household customers/multiple residential
complexes/commercial establishments on the automated trash collection system
shall be kept in a sanitary condition at all times by the resident/business.
The automated containers are owned by the city and as such, if requiring
repair, the resident/business shall contact the sanitation division to provide
repairs as needed. It shall be the responsibility of the resident/business to
ensure the automated container is not damaged or defaced in any manner other
than that which may occur under normal wear. The solid waste manager will
determine if the damage is due to neglect of the resident/business, in which
case the resident/business will be responsible for the costs incurred to
repair/replace the automated rollout container.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-38. Requirements for certain types of waste material.
(a)   Refuse. All refuse shall be placed and maintained in refuse receptacles
or containers as specified in this chapter. All refuse receptacles and
containers shall be kept covered at all times with tight-fitting lids. All
automated container lids must be sealed at the lid edges to the automated
container body. All residential trash must be placed in plastic bags prior to
placing in the refuse container. All plastic bags must be closed with either a
tie strap or tie knot.
(b)   Garbage. All garbage being placed for collection shall have been drained
of all free liquid and shall be wrapped, bagged or enclosed in paper or plastic
material before being placed in refuse receptacles or containers. Garbage
contained in refuse receptacles shall be set out to curbside only on the day of
collection. All automated container lids must be sealed at the lid edges to the
automated container body. All residential and commercial garbage must be placed
in plastic bags prior to placing same in the refuse container. All plastic bags
must be closed with either a tie strap or tie knot.
(c)   Household trash. All household trash shall be drained of all free liquid
before being placed in refuse receptacles or containers. Household trash may be
combined with garbage. Any items of household trash that are too large for
refuse receptacles and cannot be reduced to a size that can be placed in a
refuse receptacle may be placed at curbside, provided such items are covered or
secured to avoid their dispersal by the elements. Prior to placement at the
curbside, household customers shall contact the sanitation division to arrange
collection. Household trash contained in refuse receptacles shall be set out to
curbside only on the day of collection.
(d)   Dangerous refuse items. All dangerous refuse and all waste material of
any injurious nature, such as broken glass, light bulbs, sharp pieces of metal,
fluorescent tubes and television picture tubes, shall not simply be placed in
paper or plastic bags but shall instead, be securely wrapped to prevent injury
to collection personnel. Additionally, items such as car parts, chicken wire,
concrete, metals, pipes or similar type items shall not be placed in any refuse
receptacle used for collection by the city nor shall such items be collected by
the city.
(e)   Hazardous refuse and building materials. Hazardous refuse or building
materials shall not be placed in any refuse receptacle used for collection by
the city nor shall such material be collected by the city.
(f)   Brush trimmings. All brush trimmings shall be collected by the city when
placed at curbside for collection by 7:00 a.m. on the Monday of the collection
week as determined by the solid waste manager. Loose brush trimmings shall not
be placed on storm drains, or on or under utility guy wires, low-hanging
utility wires, utility pedestals, meter boxes, or other utility structures. If
brush trimmings are placed in reusable brush containers, such containers shall
not weigh more than 50 pounds, shall not accumulate rainwater, and shall be
clearly marked as "brush" or "leaves". Approved biodegradable paper yard waste
bags containing brush trimmings shall not weigh more than 25 pounds. No tree
trunks, stumps, branches, limbs or shrubbery trimmings larger than six inches
in diameter, longer than four feet, or weighing more than 50 pounds shall be
collected by the city. Tree and shrubbery limbs shall have protruding branches
trimmed and may be placed in piles at curbside only if placed separately from
thorny vegetation. Thorny vegetation, if placed at curbside for collection,
shall be cut in lengths not to exceed two feet and shall be placed in separate
piles from other tree and shrubbery trimmings. No grass clippings shall be
collected with brush trimmings.
(g)   Contractor work: Tree and shrubbery branches, limbs and trimmings cut by
persons engaged in landscaping or tree service enterprises or by other
commercial operations or resulting from land clearing operations shall not be
collected by the city. Contractor work shall be defined as any work engaged in
for profit, and the removal of such branches, trimmings or land clearing debris
shall be performed at the expense of the contractor.
(h)   Leaves: Leaves shall be stored for collection in approved biodegradable
paper yard waste bags or in approved marked reusable brush containers
designated as "brush" or "leaves." The contents of such containers shall not
extend above the rim thereof and shall be contained so as to prevent rainwater
accumulation and to prevent the elements from carrying or depositing contents
upon any street, sidewalk, public, or private property. Approved paper bags and
reusable brush containers containing leaves clearly marked "brush" or "leaves"
shall be placed at curbside for collection by 7:00 a.m. on the Monday of the
collection week as determined by the solid waste manager. No grass clippings
shall be collected with leaves.
(i)   Special collection of household furniture and appliances. Upon request
the city may collect normal household discarded furniture and appliances,
including sofas, chairs, beds, mattresses, bedsprings, refrigerators, washers,
dryers, hot water heaters and similar items, unless otherwise provided in this
chapter. Furnaces shall not be collected by the city. Persons requesting this
service shall contact the solid waste division to schedule collection. Items
for collection shall be placed at their appropriate location, curbside. This
service shall be available to residences only.
(j)   Business trash. Business trash (except cardboard boxes, cartons or
crates), shall be placed in plastic bags and tied before being placed in refuse
receptacles or containers. When full, plastic bags containing business trash
shall not weight more than 25 pounds.
(k)   Commercial establishments. The solid waste manager shall notify all
merchants and other commercial users of the schedule of pickup, and the
merchants and other commercial users shall comply by setting their refuse
receptacles at curbside in accordance with this schedule.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08; Ord. No. 4993, § 1, 1-10-23)
Sec. 15-39. Location and collection.
(a)   All accumulations of refuse and trash shall be stored or placed for
collection in accordance with the following:
(1)   Public streets. No refuse, trash, brush, leaves, tree and shrubbery
trimmings refuse receptacle or bulk container shall be placed within the
vehicular travel-way, in the gutter of any street, or in the vehicle travel-way
in areas not having curbs and gutters.
(2)   Public sidewalks. Refuse, trash, brush, leaves or tree and shrubbery
trimmings contained in approved refuse receptacles may be placed on the
sidewalk on the day of collection, so long as it does not unreasonably
interfere with pedestrian traffic.
(3)   Public alleys. Refuse contained in approved refuse receptacles may be
placed in a public alley on the day of collection, so long as it does not
unreasonably interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
(4)   Blockage of storm drains. No person shall place any refuse, trash, refuse
receptacle or container on, upon or over any storm drain opening or so close
thereto as to be drawn by the elements into the drain. No person shall place
any refuse, trash, refuse receptacle or container in a gutter, which results in
the blockage of stormwater flows or possible blockage of storm drainage systems
if carried by the elements into the drainage system. Failure of the owner or
occupant to remove and correct the blockage of storm drain openings and/or
obstruction of stormwater flows shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.
(5)   Private streets. Refuse contained in approved refuse receptacles may be
collected along private streets provided that both: (a) the owner(s) of the
private street executes a private road agreement authorizing the city to use
the private street for the purpose of solid waste collection; and (b) the owner
(s) acknowledge and agree that he/she/they have the affirmative obligation and
responsibility to ensure that the private street is continuously maintained and
kept in good repair such that, in the determination of the Public Works
Director or their designee, it is safe for use by city solid waste collectors
and their vehicles. The city shall have no responsibility for the maintenance
and repair of the private street.
(b)   The accumulation and storage of refuse and trash under the following
circumstances shall be prohibited:
(1)   The accumulation of refuse or trash on any lot, property, premises,
public street, sidewalk, alley or other public or private place. Failure of the
owner or occupant, after notice of violation, to remove and correct any such
unauthorized accumulation of refuse or trash shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter.
(2)   To place or store outside any building or dwelling, except as provided in
this chapter, any dilapidated furniture, appliances, machinery, equipment,
building materials or any other item which is either in a wholly or partially
rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition and which is not
completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. This shall not apply to
authorized junk dealers or authorized establishments engaged in the business of
repairing, rebuilding, reconditioning or salvage.
(3)   Appliances. To leave outside any building or dwelling, (in a place
accessible to children), any appliance, refrigerator or other container of any
kind which has an airtight door or cover with a snap lock or latch without
first removing the lock/latch, from the door/cover.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08; Ord. No. 5149, § 1, 6-24-25)
Sec. 15-40. Commercial establishments.
(a)   Household customers, multiple residential complexes and commercial
establishments that do not have automated trash collection on the city's
automated trash collection system. Every person who is in possession or control
of any place in or from which business trash, garbage, household trash, or
industrial waste is accumulated or produced shall be required to provide, and
at all times, keep receptacles and containers in a suitable place. Such
receptacles and containers should be readily accessible to city collection
crews or private collection agencies. City collection crews and/or private
collection agencies will not remove any form of waste which is not readily
accessible. Adequate and suitable receptacles and containers capable of holding
all specified waste material, which would ordinarily accumulate between the
times of successive collections, are required. Such collection shall be limited
to a maximum of six refuse receptacles. The solid waste manager shall determine
the quantity, type and location of such receptacles or containers (as provided
in this chapter), and shall be authorized to determine whether such receptacles
and containers are serviceable and sanitary.
(b)   Household customers, multiple residential complexes and commercial
establishments that receive automated trash collection service. The solid waste
manager shall determine if automated trash collection service is applicable to
an individual's residence or business. Every person who is in possession or
control of any place in or from which business trash, garbage, household trash,
or industrial waste is accumulated or produced shall be provided, at no cost to
the household, with a specialized automated roll-out container designed
specifically for use with the automated trash collection truck. The specialized
containers are the property of the city and shall be left at the residence/
business should the original owners move. Additionally, the solid waste manager
shall determine the location of such containers, as provided in this chapter.
The resident/business has an option to rent additional containers over the one
automated container provided, subject to the applicable requirements set forth
in article II, subsection
15-36(b) of this chapter.
(c)   The public work director shall review the method and location of refuse
storage for new commercial buildings or extensive renovations to existing
commercial buildings. If any problems are foreseen during this review, such
problems shall be called to the attention of the owner or designer for
correction.
(d)   It shall be unlawful for any commercial establishment to put business
trash in any street refuse receptacle or container maintained by the city. All
businesses must use their own refuse containers for trash disposal. Any
commercial business using city owned street receptacles or containers for their
private use shall be deemed in violation of this chapter.
(e)   Multiple residential complexes and commercial establishments are limited
to one collection per week by the city and are considered a single unit subject
to the same service as contained in subsections (a) and (b) of this section.
Multiple residential complexes and commercial establishments shall be provided
one specialized container which is owned by the city to the extent the location
is serviced by the city's automated trash collection service. If a need exists
for additional specialized containers, containers will be available for rent,
from the city, on a monthly basis. Rental fees and charges for additional
containers shall be set forth in the city's Fees and Charges Manual.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-41. Loading and unloading areas.
All loading and unloading areas shall, at the direction of the solid waste
manager be provided with refuse receptacles or containers for loose papers,
debris, packaging materials and other business trash. The number and type of
such containers necessary for each area shall be as required to maintain clean,
neat and litter-free premises as directed by the city's solid waste manager
based upon the industry's standard.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-42. Parking lots.
(a)   Obligation to furnish receptacles. All parking lots and establishments
with parking lots shall provide refuse receptacles within the parking areas.
The solid waste manager shall have the authority to determine the number of
receptacles necessary to provide adequate containerization. Such receptacles
shall be weighted or attached to the ground to prevent spillage. It shall be
the responsibility of the owner or the person in charge of the parking lot to
collect the refuse and trash deposited in such containers and store this
material in an approved location.
(b)   Obligation to use receptacles. It shall be the obligation of all persons
using parking areas to use such refuse receptacles or containers as provided
for the purposes intended, and it shall be a violation of this chapter for any
person to dump, scatter or throw upon any such parking lot any refuse, garbage
or trash of any kind.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-43. Construction and demolition sites.
All construction and demolition contractors shall provide onsite refuse
receptacles, bulk containers or detachable containers for loose debris, paper,
waste building materials, scrap building materials and other trash produced by
those working on the site. All such materials shall be containerized by the end
of each workday, and the site shall be kept in a reasonably clean and litter-
free condition. The number and type of refuse receptacles, bulk containers or
detachable containers shall be determined by the solid waste manager based on
the size of the project. Dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris
deposited upon any public or private property as a result of construction or
demolition activities shall be immediately removed by the contractor and in all
cases by the end of the workday.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-44. Points of collection.
(a)   On the day of collection, unless otherwise provided by this chapter, it
shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant to place refuse
receptacles at curbside or at the edge of the vehicular travel-way. It is also
the responsibility of the owner or occupant to place receptacles or containers
in front of their respective residence (i.e. curbside of their property) for
collection unless otherwise specified by the solid waste manager/designee.
Receptacles, containers, or other material for pickup will not be collected
unless these specifications are met. No refuse receptacles or containers,
unless otherwise provided in this chapter, shall be stored in front of a
building or dwelling except on the day of collection.
(1)   Household customers, multiple residential complexes and commercial
establishments not receiving automated trash collection must place their trash
at curbside not being blocked by parked cars or any other objects in order to
allow for easy access to the refuse receptacles by 7:00 a.m. the day of
collection.
(2)   Household customers, multiple residential complexes and commercial
establishments receiving automated trash collection service shall place the
city owned automated rollout container:
(i)   At least five feet from any obstacle (including cars, trees, utility
poles, and/or mailboxes).
(ii)   Within two feet of the curb edge.
(iii)   Away from low hanging utilities.
(iv)   Automated rollout containers must be turned so the handle faces away
from the street.
(v)   At curbside by 7:00 a.m. of their collection day.
(3)   Household customers, multiple residential complexes and commercial
establishments located in the Central Business District must place their trash
at curbside not being blocked by parked cars or any other objects in order to
allow for easy access to the refuse receptacles by 5:00 a.m. on their
collection day.
(b)   Failure to comply with points of collection of refuse receptacles and
automated rollout containers will be deemed a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-45. Collection and hauling procedures.
(a)   Household customers not on the city's automated trash collection system:
Residential. Garbage and household trash accumulated at residences shall be
collected once each week at curbside or at the edge of the vehicular travel-
way. In accordance with a schedule determined by the solid waste manager, such
collections shall be limited to six approved receptacles.
(b)   Household customers and multiple residential complexes on the city's
automated trash collection system. Garbage and household trash accumulated at
residences shall be collected once each week at curbside or at the edge of the
vehicular travel-way. In accordance with a schedule determined by the solid
waste manager, no other refuse containers except city owned rollout containers
will be collected.
(c)   Oversize household trash. Oversized household trash shall be collected on
a schedule determined by the solid waste manager at curbside, as specified in
this chapter. Prior to placement at the curbside, the household customer must
contact the sanitation division to arrange collection.
(d)   Commercial establishments not on the city's automated trash collection
system. Such collection shall be limited to six approved receptacles on a
weekly schedule determined by the solid waste manager.
(e)   Commercial establishments on the automated trash collection system. The
solid waste manager shall only collect the city owned automated rollout
containers on a weekly schedule determined by the solid waste manager.
(f)   Bulk containers. Bulk containers shall at all times be maintained in a
safe, serviceable and sanitary condition as directed by the solid waste
manager. Notice shall be given by the solid waste manager of any bulk container
not meeting the requirements of this chapter. Every person who shall engage in
the leasing, renting or supplying, (by manner other than absolute sale, bulk
containers, detachable containers and portable packing units) to persons to
whom this chapter applies shall operate and maintain facilities and equipment
for servicing, cleaning, repairing and painting such containers and units. In
addition, such persons shall maintain such units in a safe, serviceable and
sanitary condition as required by this chapter.
(g)   Roll-out containers. Roll-out containers for sale within the city limits
are not acceptable for use with the automated trash collection system. Roll-out
containers for sale in the city limits may be acceptable for residents/
businesses not on the automated collection system. The solid waste manager
shall be responsible for final determination of the acceptability and
compatibility of any roll-out containers offered for sale within the city
limits of the city, which determination shall include but not limited to the
following:
(1)   Capacity. Capacity of 80 to 100 gallons;
(2)   Hinged lid. Lid for roll-out container shall be affixed to the container
by a hinge-type device;
(3)   Container design. Container shall be of design that allows container to
be easily rolled when filled.
(h)   Prohibited collections: The solid waste manager shall not collect the
following type of waste:
(1)   Industrial waste. The collection and disposal of industrial waste shall
be the responsibility of the operator of the factory, plant or enterprise
creating or causing the waste.
(2)   Hazardous refuse. No hazardous refuse shall be placed in any receptacle,
container or unit used for refuse collection by the city. Hazardous liquids or
highly combustible industrial waste shall not be disposed of in the landfill.
(3)   Dead animals. Small dead animals will be collected by the city on
request, provided that it is during the operating hours of the landfill and the
body is in a place easily accessible to the collector and is wrapped or
contained in a plastic bag or other suitable container that will be collected
with the body. Owners of large dead animals shall be responsible for their
removal and disposal.
(4)   Building materials. The city shall not be responsible for the collecting,
handling or disposal of building materials that originate from private property
preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings or
from demolition of existing structures. Such materials or refuse shall be
collected and disposed of by the property owner or the person doing the work.
If such material or refuse has not been removed and disposed of by the property
owner or the person doing the work, the building inspections division shall not
issue a certificate of occupancy even though other requirements for such
certificate have been met. The certificate of occupancy shall be issued only
when the requirements of this subsection, as well as any other requirements,
have been met.
(5)   Corrugated cardboard will not be collected as municipal solid waste in
any shape or form. Corrugated cardboard is collected through the city's
recycling program only.
(i)   Hauling vehicles. All collectors or refuse haulers or handlers operating
within the city shall use a watertight vehicle provided with a tightly fitting
cover and so operated as to prevent offensive odors escaping there from and
refuse from being dropped, blown or spilled. These vehicles shall also be kept
in good repair and shall be cleaned as often as necessary to prevent the body
of the vehicle from becoming a breeding place for insects or a source of foul
or offensive odors.
(j)   Spilling of vehicle loads. Any person engaged in hauling or transporting
dirt, crushed stone, coal or other loose material for any purpose whatever
through any street, lane, alley or public way of the city shall haul or
transport the material in vehicles with tight bodies and so constructed and
equipped that the contents shall not fall on any street or sidewalk.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-46. Post collection procedures.
Refuse receptacles returned to curbside after collection shall be removed to
the approved storage location by 11:00 p.m. of the day of collection. The
property owner or occupant shall be responsible for such removal.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-47. Special refuse or disposal problems.
(a)   Contagious disease refuse. The removal of clothing, bedding or other
refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have
prevailed shall be performed under the supervision and direction of the county
health department. Such refuse shall not be placed in containers for city
collection and disposal.
(b)   Hypodermic instruments. No person shall dispose of or discard any
hypodermic needle or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections
before first breaking, disassembling, destroying or otherwise rendering
inoperable and incapable of reuse such hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument
or device and without safeguarding the disposal thereof by wrapping or securing
the device in a suitable manner to avoid the possibility of causing injury to
collection personnel.
(c)   Ashes. Ashes that are to be collected by the city shall have been wetted
and shall be cool to the touch prior to collection. Ashes shall be placed in
approved containers. Refuse receptacles containing ashes shall not weigh more
than 50 pounds.
(d)   Rubber tires. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to
place any rubber tire that has not been reduced from its original shape or
conformation by a generally accepted and approved manner or method in any
refuse receptacle or container from which refuse is collected by the city or by
private waste collectors within the city.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-48. Special service.
Hardship cases such as age, disability or infirmity, when confirmed by the
solid waste manager may be afforded the special service of refuse receptacle
carryout and carry-back upon application.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
ARTICLE III. RECYCLING
Sec. 15-49. Purpose.
Declaration of policy. This article has been created pursuant to NCGS §§ 160A-
317 and 130A-309.09, and due to the great public interest in preserving the
environment by reducing the amount of refuse sent to landfills. Because of
solid waste disposal problems and the potential solution to some of these
problems provided by recycling, it shall be the policy of the city to require
recycling to the fullest extent possible of recyclable materials designated by
the city.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-50. Administration.
(a)   Recycling coordinator position. The position of recycling coordinator is
hereby established. In addition to the duties of solid waste manager, the solid
waste manager or designee shall also serve in the position of recycling
coordinator. The collection, removal, and disposal of materials designated as
recyclable by the city shall be supervised by the recycling coordinator.
(b)   Recycling coordinator office. The office of recycling coordinator is
hereby authorized, subject to the direction and control of the director, to
develop a comprehensive recycling education program and coordinate publicity
and educate the household customer in implementing the collection of recyclable
materials.
(c)   Responsibilities of the recycling coordinator:
(1)   The office of the recycling coordinator is responsible for
administratively coordinating the transportation and delivery of recyclable
materials from the city's household customers to processing facilities. The
office of the recycling coordinator shall, for all purposes, be the liaison for
communicating all issues, concerns, requests or inquiries regarding the city's
recycling program.
(2)   The office of the recycling coordinator shall assist business, commercial
establishments and multi- family dwellings in setting up recycling programs to
be offered by private or public solid waste management services.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Sec. 15-51. Regulations.
(a)   Recyclable materials. All recyclable materials generated by a household
customer shall be separated from municipal solid waste and placed in recycling
receptacles for curbside collection or taken to collection facilities.
Recyclable materials shall consist of the following:
Aluminum cans
Corrugated cardboard
Glass bottles and jars (clear, green, and brown)
Newsprint and inserts that are distributed as part of the publication
Plastic bottles and containers
Steel cans
Tin cans
Mixed paper
Additional materials as directed by the recycling coordinator
(b)   Collection of recyclable materials.
(1)   Only the materials designated for recycling in subsection (a) shall be
placed in recycling receptacles provided by the city or its contractor.
(2)   If the amount of recyclable materials is greater than the recycling
receptacle provided, such materials shall be placed in clearly marked reusable
containers adjacent to the recycling receptacle on designated collection date
(s).
(3)   Recycling receptacles shall be placed at curbside or other designated
spot on the customer's premises for collection on days specified by the office
of the recycling coordinator.
(4)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place any municipal solid waste
not designated for recycling in subsection (a) of this section in the recycling
receptacles furnished by the city or the city's contractor.
(5)   After collection, empty receptacles shall be removed promptly by the
customer by 11:00 p.m. on the same day as collection.
(6)   Recyclable materials that are taken to a collection facility owned by the
city or provided by the city's contractor shall be placed in the appropriate
container at the collection facility.
(7)   An information package about the recycling program shall be delivered to
each household customer upon delivery of the recycling receptacle.
(c)   Scavenging and unauthorized collection of recyclable materials.
(1)   Recyclable materials placed at curbside for collection by the city or its
contractor or in any recycling receptacle sponsored by the city are the
property of the city or its authorized contractor. It is a violation of this
article for any person not authorized by the city to collect or pick up, or
cause to be collected or picked up, any such recyclable materials or
receptacles.
(2)   Nothing in this section is intended to prevent any occupier of land from
donating or selling recyclable material from its own municipal solid waste.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
ARTICLE IV. ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 15-52. Civil penalty.
(a)   Notice required before penalty. No penalty shall be assessed pursuant to
this chapter until the person alleged to be in violation has been notified of
the violation in accordance with this section:
(1)   Notice of violation. Whenever any city official charged with the duty of
enforcing the regulations in this chapter has reasonable cause to believe that
a person is violating any of the provisions of this chapter or that real
property within the city is in violation of this chapter, that official shall
notify the alleged violator and/or property owner of the violation, providing
for up to 30 days to comply with the requirements of this chapter. If the
violator cannot be ascertained, then the notice of violation shall be sent to
the record owner of the land on which the violation exists.
(2)   Service requirements. Notices of violation shall be in writing and shall
be served by personal delivery or by certified or registered mail, return
receipt requested. The notice of violation shall specify the violation, what
must be done to remedy the violation, an opportunity to cure the violation
within a prescribed period of time and the consequences of non-compliance.
(3)   Extension of time to cure. The city official charged with the duty of
enforcing this chapter may upon written request from the alleged violator or
the property owner, grant a single extension of time, not to exceed a period of
30 days in which the alleged violator may cure or correct the violation before
the city issues a citation as set forth herein.
(4)   Citation for violation. Any person who fails to comply with a notice of
violation issued under this chapter within the time period set forth in the
notice of violation or within any authorized extensions granted, shall be
subject to a civil penalty in the amount of $100.00 per day the violation
continues with each day of violation constituting a separate and distinct
violation. In no event, shall be amount of the civil penalty arising out of the
original notice of violation exceed $5,000.00. The city shall serve a written
citation on the alleged violator in accordance with the service requirements
set forth above for a notice of violation. The citation shall specify the date
the penalty commenced, that the penalty is in the amount of $100.00 per day the
penalty continues and shall continue to accrue at the rate of $100.00 per day
until either the violation is brought into compliance with the provisions of
this chapter or the penalty reaches $5,000.00, whichever occurs first. To be
deemed in compliance, the owner must give the city written notice of the
corrective action taken. The citation shall state that the penalty shall be
paid within 30 days of the date of the issuance of the citation and if not
paid, that the matter will be referred to the city attorney to institute a
civil action in the nature of a debt owed. If the civil penalty is not paid
and/or if the violation is not cured within the time frames set forth in the
citation and notice of violation respectively, the matter shall be referred to
the city attorney for the institution of a civil action in the name of the city
in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect the amount owed and to
otherwise obtain compliance with this chapter.
(b)   Equitable action. In addition to or in lieu of other remedies as set
forth herein, the city attorney may seek injunctive relief, an order of
abatement or other appropriate relief in the appropriate court of law.
(c)   Emergency abatement. Nothing herein shall prevent the city from
immediately proceeding in the absence of prior notice to abate an imminent
threat to life or property. As soon as the imminent threat is removed, notice
shall be given within a reasonable time period thereafter consistent with the
requirements of this article.
(d)   Refuse to remove. The director shall not be obligated to cause the
retrieval and removal of any required contents from any real property as set
forth under this chapter, if after proper notice, the customer and tenant or
property owner as applicable, fail and refuse to comply with the provisions of
article II for storage and collection under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 3625, § 1, 5-27-08)
Chapter 16 STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES  1

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 16-1. Obstruction and deposit of debris.
(a)   The streets and sidewalks of the city shall be kept free of all
obstructions and open to traffic at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any
person to deposit any article or do any act which obstructs such streets and
sidewalks.
(b)   It shall be unlawful for the owner or any contractor engaged in
construction or improvement of any property abutting upon streets and sidewalks
of the city to allow the deposit of any mud, dirt, construction material or
other debris upon such streets and sidewalks.
(c)   If the person responsible for obstructing streets or sidewalks, as
prohibited in subsection (a) of this section, or depositing mud, dirt,
construction material or debris on streets or sidewalks, as prohibited in
subsection (b) of this section, after due notice, fails to remove such
obstruction, dirt, mud, construction material or other debris, the director of
public works is hereby authorized to effect the removal thereof, and in
addition to all other remedies, the city may assess costs incurred by it which
shall be a lien against the property from which any obstruction, dirt, mud,
construction material or other debris has been removed and deposited upon the
streets and sidewalks of the city.
(d)   In addition to and separate and apart from the other remedies set forth
in this section, a violator of any of the provisions of this section may be
assessed a civil penalty as set forth in section
1-5, and each and every day during which a violation occurs shall be a separate
and distinct offense.
(Code 1965, § 25-3)
State law reference(s)—Driving motor vehicle on sidewalk prohibited, G.S. 20-
160; placing glass or injurious obstruction upon highway prohibited, G.S. 136-
91; city's duty to keep public streets free from unnecessary obstructions, G.S.
160A- 296(a)(2); authorization to prohibit placing trash on streets, G.S. 160A-
303.1.
Sec. 16-2. Obstruction of streets, sidewalks by persons prohibited.
(a)   It shall be unlawful for any person, singly or in a group, to:
(1)   Obstruct or cause to be obstructed vehicular or pedestrian traffic on the
streets or sidewalks or in parks or other public areas within the corporate
limits of the city; or
